00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
than in urban.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
And Bertie County is no exception to this.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
Perhaps the biggest thing it struggles with,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
like many communities similar to it,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
is that there's no

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
shared, collective investment

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
in the future of rural communities.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
Only 6.8 percent of all our philanthropic giving in the U.S. right now

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
benefits rural communities,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and yet 20 percent of our population lives there.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
So Bertie County is not only very rural; it's incredibly poor.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
It is the poorest county in the state.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
It has one in three of its children living in poverty,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
and it's what is referred to as a "rural ghetto."

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
The economy is mostly agricultural.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
The biggest crops are cotton and tobacco,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
and we're very proud of our Bertie County peanut.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
The biggest employer is the Purdue chicken processing plant.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
The county seat is Windsor.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
This is like Times Square of Windsor that you're looking at right now.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
It's home to only 2,000 people,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and like a lot of other small towns

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
it has been hollowed out over the years.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
There are more buildings that are empty or in disrepair

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
than occupied and in use.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
You can count the number of restaurants in the county

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
on one hand --

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
Bunn's Barbecue being my absolute favorite.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
But in the whole county there is no coffee shop,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
there's no Internet cafe,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
there's no movie theater, there's no bookstore.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
There isn't even a Walmart.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
Racially, the county

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
is about 60 percent African-American,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
but what happens in the public schools

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
is most of the privileged white kids

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
go to the private Lawrence Academy.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
So the public school students

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
are about 86 percent African-American.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And this is a spread from the local newspaper of the recent graduating class,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and you can see the difference is pretty stark.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
So to say that the public education system

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
in Bertie County is struggling

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
would be a huge understatement.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
There's basically no pool

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
of qualified teachers to pull from,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
and only eight percent of the people in the county

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
have a bachelor's degree or higher.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
So there isn't a big legacy

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
in the pride of education.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
In fact, two years ago,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
only 27 percent of all the third- through eighth-graders

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
were passing the state standard

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
in both English and math.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
So it sounds like I'm painting a really bleak picture of this place,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
but I promise there is good news.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
The biggest asset, in my opinion,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
one of the biggest assets in Bertie County right now is this man:

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
This is Dr. Chip Zullinger,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
fondly known as Dr. Z.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
He was brought in in October 2007

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
as the new superintendent

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
to basically fix this broken school system.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
And he previously was a superintendent

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
in Charleston, South Carolina

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
and then in Denver, Colorado.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
He started some of the country's first charter schools

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
in the late '80s in the U.S.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
And he is an absolute renegade and a visionary,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
and he is the reason that I now live and work there.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
So in February of 2009,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Dr. Zullinger invited us, Project H Design --

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
which is a non-profit design firm that I founded --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
to come to Bertie and to partner with him

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
on the repair of this school district

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
and to bring a design perspective to the repair of the school district.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And he invited us in particular

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
because we have a very specific

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
type of design process --

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
one that results in appropriate design solutions

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
in places that don't usually have access

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
to design services or creative capital.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Specifically, we use these six design directives,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
probably the most important being number two:

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
we design with, not for --

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
in that, when we're doing humanitarian-focused design,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
it's not about designing for clients anymore.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
It's about designing with people,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
and letting appropriate solutions emerge from within.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
So at the time of being invited down there,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
we were based in San Francisco,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
and so we were going back and forth

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
for basically the rest of 2009,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
spending about half our time in Bertie County.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
And when I say we, I mean Project H,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
but more specifically, I mean myself and my partner, Matthew Miller,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:06.958
who's an architect and a sort of MacGyver-type builder.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
So fast-forward to today, and we now live there.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
I have strategically cut Matt's head out of this photo,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
because he would kill me if he knew I was using it

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
because of the sweatsuits.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
But this is our front porch. We live there.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
We now call this place home.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Over the course of this year that we spent flying back and forth,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
we realized we had fallen in love with the place.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
We had fallen in love with the place and the people

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and the work that we're able to do

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
in a rural place like Bertie County,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
that, as designers and builders,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
you can't do everywhere.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
There's space to experiment

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and to weld and to test things.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
We have an amazing advocate in Dr. Zullinger.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
There's a nobility of real, hands-on,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
dirt-under-your-fingernails work.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
But beyond our personal reasons for wanting to be there,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
there is a huge need.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
There is a total vacuum of creative capital in Bertie County.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
There isn't a single licensed architect in the whole county.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And so we saw an opportunity

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
to bring design as this untouched tool,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
something that Bertie County didn't otherwise have,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and to be sort of the -- to usher that in

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
as a new type of tool in their tool kit.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
The initial goal became using design

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
within the public education system in partnership with Dr. Zullinger --

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
that was why we were there.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
But beyond that, we recognized

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
that Bertie County, as a community,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
was in dire need of a fresh perspective

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
of pride and connectedness

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and of the creative capital

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
that they were so much lacking.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
So the goal became, yes, to apply design within education,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
but then to figure out how to make education

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
a great vehicle for community development.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
So in order to do this, we've taken three different approaches

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
to the intersection of design and education.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And I should say that these are three things that we've done in Bertie County,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
but I feel pretty confident that they could work

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
in a lot of other rural communities

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
around the U.S. and maybe even beyond.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
So the first of the three is design for education.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
This is the most kind of direct, obvious

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
intersection of the two things.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
It's the physical construction

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
of improved spaces and materials and experiences

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
for teachers and students.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
This is in response to the awful mobile trailers

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and the outdated textbooks

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and the terrible materials that we're building schools out of these days.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
And so this played out for us in a couple different ways.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
The first was a series of renovations of computer labs.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
So traditionally, the computer labs,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
particularly in an under-performing school like Bertie County,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
where they have to benchmark test every other week,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
the computer lab is a kill-and-drill

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
testing facility.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
You come in, you face the wall, you take your test and you leave.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
So we wanted to change the way that students approach technology,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
to create a more convivial and social space

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
that was more engaging, more accessible,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and also to increase the ability for teachers

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
to use these spaces for technology-based instruction.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
So this is the lab at the high school,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and the principal there is in love with this room.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
Every time he has visitors, it's the first place that he takes them.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
And this also meant the co-creation with some teachers

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
of this educational playground system

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
called the learning landscape.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
It allows elementary-level students to learn core subjects

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
through game play and activity

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and running around and screaming and being a kid.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
So this game that the kids are playing here --

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
in this case they were learning basic multiplication

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
through a game called Match Me.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And in Match Me, you take the class, divide it into two teams,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
one team on each side of the playground,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
and the teacher will take a piece of chalk

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and just write a number on each of the tires.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And then she'll call out a math problem --

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
so let's say four times four --

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and then one student from each team has to compete

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
to figure out that four times four is 16

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
and find the tire with the 16 on it and sit on it.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
So the goal is to have all of your teammates sitting on the tires

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and then your team wins.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And the impact of the learning landscape

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
has been pretty surprising and amazing.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Some of the classes and teachers have reported higher test scores,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
a greater comfort level with the material,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
especially with the boys,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
that in going outside and playing,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
they aren't afraid to take on

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
a double-digit multiplication problem --

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and also that the teachers are able

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
to use these as assessment tools

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
to better gauge how their students

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
are understanding new material.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So with design for education, I think the most important thing

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
is to have a shared ownership of the solutions with the teachers,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
so that they have the incentive and the desire to use them.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
So this is Mr. Perry. He's the assistant superintendent.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
He came out for one of our teacher-training days

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
and won like five rounds of Match Me in a row and was very proud of himself.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
(Laughter)

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
So the second approach is redesigning education itself.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
This is the most complex.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
It's a systems-level look

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
at how education is administered

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and what is being offered and to whom.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
So in many cases this is not so much about making change

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
as it is creating the conditions

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
under which change is possible

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
and the incentive to want to make change,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
which is easier said than done in rural communities

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
and in inside-the-box education systems

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
in rural communities.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
So for us, this was a graphic public campaign

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
called Connect Bertie.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
There are thousands of these blue dots all over the county.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And this was for a fund that the school district had

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
to put a desktop computer and a broadband Internet connection

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
in every home

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
with a child in the public school system.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Right now I should say,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
there are only 10 percent of the houses

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
that actually have an in-home Internet connection.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
And the only places to get WiFi

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
are in the school buildings, or at the Bojangles Fried Chicken joint,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
which I find myself squatting outside of a lot.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Aside from, you know, getting people excited

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
and wondering what the heck these blue dots were all over the place,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
it asked the school system

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
to envision how it might become a catalyst

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
for a more connected community.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
It asked them to reach outside of the school walls

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and to think about how they could play a role

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
in the community's development.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
So the first batch of computers

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
are being installed later this summer,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and we're helping Dr. Zullinger develop some strategies

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
around how we might connect the classroom and the home

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
to extend learning beyond the school day.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And then the third approach, which is what I'm most excited about,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
which is where we are now,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
is: design as education.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
So "design as education" means

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
that we could actually teach design within public schools,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and not design-based learning --

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
not like "let's learn physics by building a rocket,"

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
but actually learning design-thinking

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
coupled with real construction and fabrication skills

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
put towards a local community purpose.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
It also means that designers are no longer consultants,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
but we're teachers,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and we are charged with growing creative capital

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
within the next generation.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And what design offers as an educational framework

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
is an antidote

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
to all of the boring, rigid, verbal instruction

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
that so many of these school districts are plagued by.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
It's hands-on, it's in-your-face,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
it requires an active engagement,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and it allows kids to apply all the core subject learning

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
in real ways.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
So we started thinking

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
about the legacy of shop class

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and how shop class -- wood and metal shop class in particular --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
historically, has been something

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
intended for kids who aren't going to go to college.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
It's a vocational training path.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It's working-class; it's blue-collar.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
The projects are things like,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
let's make a birdhouse for your mom for Christmas.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And in recent decades, a lot of the funding for shop class

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
has gone away entirely.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
So we thought, what if you could bring back shop class,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
but this time orient the projects

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
around things that the community needed,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and to infuse shop class

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
with a more critical and creative-design-thinking studio process.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
So we took this kind of nebulous idea

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and have worked really closely with Dr. Zullinger for the past year

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
on writing this as a one-year curriculum

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
offered at the high school level to the junior class.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And so this starts in four weeks,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
at the end of the summer,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
and my partner and I, Matthew and I,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
just went through the arduous and totally convoluted process

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
of getting certified as high school teachers to actually run it.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And this is what it looks like.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So over the course of two semesters,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
the Fall and the Spring,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
the students spend three hours a day every single day

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
in our 4,500 square foot

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
studio/shop space.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
And during that time, they're doing everything

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
from going out and doing ethnographic research and doing the need-finding,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
coming back into the studio,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
doing the brainstorming and design visualization

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
to come up with concepts that might work,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and then moving into the shop and actually testing them,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
building them, prototyping them,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
figuring out if they are going to work and refining that.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And then over the summer, they're offered a summer job.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
They're paid as employees of Project H

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
to be the construction crew with us

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
to build these projects in the community.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
So the first project, which will be built next summer,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
is an open-air farmers' market downtown,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
followed by bus shelters for the school bus system in the second year

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
and home improvements for the elderly in the third year.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
So these are real visible projects

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
that hopefully the students can point to and say,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
"I built that, and I'm proud of it."

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
So I want you to meet three of our students.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
This is Ryan.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
She is 15 years old.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
She loves agriculture and wants to be a high school teacher.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
She wants to go to college, but she wants to come back to Bertie County,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
because that's where her family is from, where she calls home,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and she feels very strongly about giving back

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
to this place that she's been fairly fortunate in.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
So what Studio H might offer her

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
is a way to develop skills

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
so that she might give back in the most meaningful way.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
This is Eric. He plays for the football team.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
He is really into dirtbike racing,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
and he wants to be an architect.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
So for him, Studio H offers him

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
a way to develop the skills he will need as an architect,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
everything from drafting to wood and metal construction

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
to how to do research for a client.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And then this is Anthony.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
He is 16 years old, loves hunting and fishing and being outside

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and doing anything with his hands,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and so for him, Studio H means

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
that he can stay interested in his education

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
through that hands-on engagement.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
He's interested in forestry, but he isn't sure,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
so if he ends up not going to college,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
he will have developed some industry-relevant skills.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
What design and building really offers to public education

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
is a different kind of classroom.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
So this building downtown,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
which may very well become the site of our future farmers' market,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
is now the classroom.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And going out into the community and interviewing your neighbors

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
about what kind of food they buy

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
and from where and why --

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
that's a homework assignment.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
And the ribbon-cutting ceremony at the end of the summer

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
when they have built the farmers' market and it's open to the public --

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
that's the final exam.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
And for the community, what design and building offers

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
is real, visible, built progress.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
It's one project per year,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and it makes the youth the biggest asset

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and the biggest untapped resource

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
in imagining a new future.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So we recognize that Studio H, especially in its first year,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
is a small story --

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
13 students, it's two teachers,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
it's one project in one place.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
But we feel like this could work in other places.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And I really, strongly believe in the power of the small story,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
because it is so difficult

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
to do humanitarian work at a global scale.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Because, when you zoom out that far,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
you lose the ability to view people as humans.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Ultimately, design itself is a process

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
of constant education

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
for the people that we work with and for

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and for us as designers.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And let's face it, designers, we need to reinvent ourselves.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
We need to re-educate ourselves around the things that matter,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
we need to work outside of our comfort zones more,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and we need to be better citizens in our own backyard.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
So while this is a very small story,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
we hope that it represents a step in the right direction

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
for the future of rural communities

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and for the future of public education

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
and hopefully also for the future of design.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Thank you.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:33.958
(Applause)

title: The path to ending ethnic conflicts
transcript: Today I want to talk to you about ethnic conflict and civil war. These are not normally the most cheerful of topics, nor do they generally generate the kind of good news that this conference is about. Yet, not only is there at least some good news to be told about fewer such conflicts now than two decades ago, but what is perhaps more important is that we also have come to a much better understanding of what can be done to further reduce the number of ethnic conflicts and civil wars and the suffering that they inflict. Three things stand out: leadership, diplomacy and institutional design. What I will focus on in my talk is why they matter, how they matter, and what we can all do to make sure that they continue to matter in the right ways, that is, how all of us can contribute to developing and honing the skills of local and global leaders to make peace and to make it last. But let's start at the beginning.Civil wars have made news headlines for many decades now, and ethnic conflicts in particular have been a near constant presence as a major international security threat. For nearly two decades now, the news has been bad and the images have been haunting. In Georgia, after years of stalemate, we saw a full-scale resurgence of violence in August, 2008. This quickly escalated into a five-day war between Russia and Georgia, leaving Georgia ever more divided. In Kenya, contested presidential elections in 2007 — we just heard about them — quickly led to high levels of inter-ethnic violence and the killing and displacement of thousands of people. In Sri Lanka, a decades-long civil war between the Tamil minority and the Sinhala majority led to a bloody climax in 2009, after perhaps as many as 100,000 people had been killed since 1983. In Kyrgyzstan, just over the last few weeks, unprecedented levels of violence occurred between ethnic Kyrgyz and ethnic Uzbeks. Hundreds have been killed, and more than 100,000 displaced, including many ethnic Uzbeks who fled to neighboring Uzbekistan. In the Middle East, conflict between Israelis and Palestinians continues unabated, and it becomes ever more difficult to see how, just how a possible, sustainable solution can be achieved. Darfur may have slipped from the news headlines, but the killing and displacement there continues as well, and the sheer human misery that it creates is very hard to fathom. And in Iraq, finally, violence is on the rise again, and the country has yet to form a government four months after its last parliamentary elections.But hang on, this talk is to be about the good news. So are these now the images of the past? Well, notwithstanding the gloomy pictures from the Middle East, Darfur, Iraq, elsewhere, there is a longer-term trend that does represent some good news. Over the past two decades, since the end of the Cold War, there has been an overall decline in the number of civil wars. Since the high in the early 1990s, with about 50 such civil wars ongoing, we now have 30 percent fewer such conflicts today. The number of people killed in civil wars also is much lower today than it was a decade ago or two. But this trend is less unambiguous. The highest level of deaths on the battlefield was recorded between 1998 and 2001, with about 80,000 soldiers, policemen and rebels killed every year. The lowest number of combatant casualties occurred in 2003, with just 20,000 killed. Despite the up and down since then, the overall trend — and this is the important bit — clearly points downward for the past two decades.The news about civilian casualties is also less bad than it used to be. From over 12,000 civilians deliberately killed in civil wars in 1997 and 1998, a decade later, this figure stands at 4,000. This is a decrease by two-thirds. This decline would be even more obvious if we factored in the genocide in Rwanda in 1994. But then 800,000 civilians were slaughtered in a matter of just a few months. This certainly is an accomplishment that must never be surpassed. What is also important is to note that these figures only tell part of the story. They exclude people that died as a consequence of civil war, from hunger or disease, for example. And they also do not properly account for civilian suffering more generally. Torture, rape and ethnic cleansing have become highly effective, if often non-lethal, weapons in civil war. To put it differently, for the civilians that suffer the consequences of ethnic conflict and civil war, there is no good war and there is no bad peace. Thus, even though every civilian killed, maimed, raped, or tortured is one too many, the fact that the number of civilian casualties is clearly lower today than it was a decade ago, is good news.So, we have fewer conflicts today in which fewer people get killed. And the big question, of course, is why? In some cases, there is a military victory of one side. This is a solution of sorts, but rarely is it one that comes without human costs or humanitarian consequences. The defeat of the Tamil Tigers in Sri Lanka is perhaps the most recent example of this, but we have seen similar so-called military solutions in the Balkans, in the South Caucasus and across most of Africa. At times, they are complimented by negotiated settlements, or at least cease-fire agreements, and peacekeepers are deployed. But hardly ever do they represent a resounding success — Bosnia and Herzegovina perhaps more so than Georgia. But for many parts of Africa, a colleague of mine once put it this way, "The cease-fire on Tuesday night was reached just in time for the genocide to start on Wednesday morning."But let's look at the good news again. If there's no solution on the battlefield, three factors can account for the prevention of ethnic conflict and civil war, or for sustainable peace afterwards: leadership, diplomacy and institutional design. Take the example of Northern Ireland. Despite centuries of animosity, decades of violence and thousands of people killed, 1998 saw the conclusion of an historic agreement. Its initial version was skillfully mediated by Senator George Mitchell. Crucially, for the long-term success of the peace process in Northern Ireland, he imposed very clear conditions for the participation and negotiations. Central among them, a commitment to exclusively peaceful means. Subsequent revisions of the agreement were facilitated by the British and Irish governments, who never wavered in their determination to bring peace and stability to Northern Ireland.The core institutions that were put in place in 1998 and their modifications in 2006 and 2008 were highly innovative and allowed all conflict parties to see their core concerns and demands addressed. The agreement combines a power-sharing arrangement in Northern Ireland with cross-border institutions that link Belfast and Dublin and thus recognizes the so-called Irish dimension of the conflict. And significantly, there's also a clear focus on both the rights of individuals and the rights of communities. The provisions in the agreement may be complex, but so is the underlying conflict. Perhaps most importantly, local leaders repeatedly rose to the challenge of compromise, not always fast and not always enthusiastically, but rise in the end they did. Who ever could have imagined Ian Paisley and Martin McGuinness jointly governing Northern Ireland as First and Deputy First Minister?But then, is Northern Ireland a unique example, or does this kind of explanation only hold more generally in democratic and developed countries? By no means. The ending of Liberia's long-lasting civil war in 2003 illustrates the importance of leadership, diplomacy and institutional design as much as the successful prevention of a full-scale civil war in Macedonia in 2001, or the successful ending of the conflict in Aceh in Indonesia in 2005. In all three cases, local leaders were willing and able to make peace, the international community stood ready to help them negotiate and implement an agreement, and the institutions have lived up to the promise that they held on the day they were agreed.Focusing on leadership, diplomacy and institutional design also helps explain failures to achieve peace, or to make it last. The hopes that were vested in the Oslo Accords did not lead to an end of the Israeli/Palestinian conflict. Not all the issues that needed to be resolved were actually covered in the agreements. Rather, local leaders committed to revisiting them later on. Yet instead of grasping this opportunity, local and international leaders soon disengaged and became distracted by the second Intifada, the events of 9/11 and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.The comprehensive peace agreement for Sudan signed in 2005 turned out to be less comprehensive than envisaged, and its provisions may yet bear the seeds of a full-scale return to war between north and south. Changes and shortcomings in leadership, more off than on international diplomacy and institutional failures account for this in almost equal measure. Unresolved boundary issues, squabbles over oil revenues, the ongoing conflict in Darfur, escalating tribal violence in the south and generally weak state capacity across all of Sudan complete a very depressing picture of the state of affairs in Africa's largest country.A final example: Kosovo. The failure to achieve a negotiated solution for Kosovo and the violence, tension and de facto partition that resulted from it have their reasons in many, many different factors. Central among them are three. First, the intransigence of local leaders to settle for nothing less than their maximum demands. Second, an international diplomatic effort that was hampered from the beginning by Western support for Kosovo's independence. And third, a lack of imagination when it came to designing institutions that could have addressed the concerns of Serbs and Albanians alike. By the same token — and here we have some good news again — the very fact that there is a high-level, well-resourced international presence in Kosovo and the Balkans region more generally and the fact that local leaders on both sides have showed relative restraint, explains why things have not been worse over the past two years since 2008.So even in situations where outcomes are less than optimal, local leaders and international leaders have a choice, and they can make a difference for the better. A cold war is not as good as a cold peace, but a cold peace is still better than a hot war. Good news is also about learning the right lesson. So what then distinguishes the Israeli/Palestinian conflict from that in Northern Ireland, or the civil war in Sudan from that in Liberia? Both successes and failures teach us several critically important things that we need to bear in mind if we want the good news to continue. First, leadership. In the same way in which ethnic conflict and civil war are not natural but man-made disasters, their prevention and settlement does not happen automatically either. Leadership needs to be capable, determined and visionary in its commitment to peace. Leaders need to connect to each other and to their followers, and they need to bring them along on what is an often arduous journey into a peaceful future.Second, diplomacy. Diplomacy needs to be well resourced, sustained, and apply the right mix of incentives and pressures on leaders and followers. It needs to help them reach an equitable compromise, and it needs to ensure that a broad coalition of local, regional and international supporters help them implement their agreement.Third, institutional design. Institutional design requires a keen focus on issues, innovative thinking and flexible and well-funded implementation. Conflict parties need to move away from maximum demands and towards a compromise that recognizes each other's needs. And they need to think about the substance of their agreement much more than about the labels they want to attach to them. Conflict parties also need to be prepared to return to the negotiation table if the agreement implementation stalls.For me personally, the most critical lesson of all is this: Local commitment to peace is all-important, but it is often not enough to prevent or end violence. Yet, no amount of diplomacy or institutional design can make up for local failures and the consequences that they have. Therefore, we must invest in developing leaders, leaders that have the skills, vision and determination to make peace. Leaders, in other words, that people will trust and that they will want to follow even if that means making hard choices.A final thought: Ending civil wars is a process that is fraught with dangers, frustrations and setbacks. It often takes a generation to accomplish, but it also requires us, today's generation, to take responsibility and to learn the right lessons about leadership, diplomacy and institutional design, so that the child soldiers of today can become the children of tomorrow.Thank you.(Applause)

killed every year.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
The lowest number of combatant casualties

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
occurred in 2003,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
with just 20,000 killed.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Despite the up and down since then,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
the overall trend --

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and this is the important bit --

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
clearly points downward

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
for the past two decades.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
The news about civilian casualties

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
is also less bad than it used to be.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
From over 12,000 civilians

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
deliberately killed in civil wars

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
in 1997 and 1998,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
a decade later,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
this figure stands at 4,000.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
This is a decrease by two-thirds.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
This decline would be even more obvious

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
if we factored in the genocide in Rwanda

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
in 1994.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
But then 800,000 civilians were slaughtered

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
in a matter of just a few months.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
This certainly is an accomplishment

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
that must never be surpassed.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
What is also important is to note

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
that these figures only tell part of the story.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
They exclude people

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
that died as a consequence of civil war,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
from hunger or disease, for example.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
And they also do not properly account

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
for civilian suffering more generally.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
Torture, rape and ethnic cleansing

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
have become highly effective,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
if often non-lethal, weapons in civil war.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
To put it differently,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
for the civilians that suffer the consequences

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
of ethnic conflict and civil war,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
there is no good war

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and there is no bad peace.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Thus, even though every civilian killed,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
maimed, raped, or tortured is one too many,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
the fact that the number

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
of civilian casualties

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
is clearly lower today

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
than it was a decade ago,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
is good news.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
So, we have fewer conflicts today

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
in which fewer people get killed.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And the big question, of course,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
is why?

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
In some cases,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
there is a military victory of one side.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
This is a solution of sorts,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
but rarely is it one

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
that comes without human costs

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
or humanitarian consequences.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
The defeat of the Tamil Tigers in Sri Lanka

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
is perhaps the most recent example of this,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
but we have seen similar

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
so-called military solutions

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
in the Balkans, in the South Caucasus

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
and across most of Africa.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
At times, they are complimented

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
by negotiated settlements,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
or at least cease-fire agreements,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and peacekeepers are deployed.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
But hardly ever do they represent

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
a resounding success --

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
Bosnia and Herzegovina

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
perhaps more so than Georgia.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
But for many parts of Africa,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
a colleague of mine once put it this way,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
"The cease-fire on Tuesday night

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
was reached just in time

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
for the genocide to start on Wednesday morning."

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
But let's look at the good news again.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
If there's no solution on the battlefield,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
three factors can account

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
for the prevention of ethnic conflict and civil war,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
or for sustainable peace afterwards:

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
leadership, diplomacy

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
and institutional design.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Take the example of Northern Ireland.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
Despite centuries of animosity,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
decades of violence

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and thousands of people killed,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
1998 saw the conclusion

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
of an historic agreement.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Its initial version was skillfully mediated

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
by Senator George Mitchell.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Crucially, for the long-term success

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
of the peace process in Northern Ireland,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
he imposed very clear conditions

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
for the participation and negotiations.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Central among them,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
a commitment

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
to exclusively peaceful means.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Subsequent revisions of the agreement

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
were facilitated by the British and Irish governments,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
who never wavered in their determination

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
to bring peace and stability to Northern Ireland.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
The core institutions

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
that were put in place in 1998

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
and their modifications

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
in 2006 and 2008

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
were highly innovative

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and allowed all conflict parties

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
to see their core concerns and demands addressed.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
The agreement combines a power-sharing arrangement

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
in Northern Ireland

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
with cross-border institutions

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
that link Belfast and Dublin

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and thus recognizes

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
the so-called Irish dimension of the conflict.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
And significantly,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
there's also a clear focus

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
on both the rights of individuals

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
and the rights of communities.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
The provisions in the agreement may be complex,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
but so is the underlying conflict.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
Perhaps most importantly,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
local leaders repeatedly rose to the challenge of compromise,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
not always fast

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and not always enthusiastically,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
but rise in the end they did.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Who ever could have imagined

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
Ian Paisley and Martin McGuinness

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
jointly governing Northern Ireland

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
as First and Deputy First Minister?

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
But then, is Northern Ireland a unique example,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
or does this kind of explanation

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
only hold more generally

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
in democratic and developed countries?

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
By no means.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
The ending of Liberia's long-lasting civil war

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
in 2003

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
illustrates the importance

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
of leadership, diplomacy

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
and institutional design

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
as much as the successful prevention

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
of a full-scale civil war

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
in Macedonia in 2001,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
or the successful ending

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
of the conflict in Aceh in Indonesia in 2005.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
In all three cases,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
local leaders were willing and able

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
to make peace,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
the international community stood ready

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
to help them negotiate and implement an agreement,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and the institutions have lived up

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
to the promise that they held

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
on the day they were agreed.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
Focusing on leadership, diplomacy

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and institutional design

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
also helps explain failures to achieve peace,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
or to make it last.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
The hopes that were vested in the Oslo Accords

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
did not lead to an end

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
of the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
Not all the issues that needed to be resolved

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
were actually covered in the agreements.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Rather, local leaders committed

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
to revisiting them later on.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Yet instead of grasping this opportunity,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
local and international leaders

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
soon disengaged

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
and became distracted

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
by the second Intifada, the events of 9/11

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
The comprehensive peace agreement for Sudan

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
signed in 2005

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
turned out to be less comprehensive than envisaged,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
and its provisions may yet bear the seeds

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
of a full-scale return to war

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
between north and south.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
Changes and shortcomings in leadership,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
more off than on international diplomacy

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and institutional failures

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
account for this

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
in almost equal measure.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Unresolved boundary issues, squabbles over oil revenues,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
the ongoing conflict in Darfur,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
escalating tribal violence in the south

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and generally weak state capacity

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
across all of Sudan

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
complete a very depressing picture

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
of the state of affairs

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in Africa's largest country.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
A final example: Kosovo.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
The failure to achieve

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
a negotiated solution for Kosovo

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and the violence, tension

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
and de facto partition that resulted from it

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
have their reasons

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
in many, many different factors.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Central among them are three.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
First, the intransigence of local leaders

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
to settle for nothing less

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
than their maximum demands.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Second, an international diplomatic effort

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
that was hampered from the beginning

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
by Western support for Kosovo's independence.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And third, a lack of imagination

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
when it came to designing institutions

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
that could have addressed the concerns

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
of Serbs and Albanians alike.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
By the same token --

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and here we have some good news again --

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
the very fact that there is a high-level,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
well-resourced international presence

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
in Kosovo

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
and the Balkans region more generally

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and the fact that local leaders on both sides

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
have showed relative restraint,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
explains why things have not been worse

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
over the past two years since 2008.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
So even in situations

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
where outcomes are less than optimal,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
local leaders

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
and international leaders have a choice,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
and they can make a difference for the better.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
A cold war

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
is not as good

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
as a cold peace,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
but a cold peace

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
is still better than a hot war.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
Good news is also about learning the right lesson.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So what then distinguishes

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
the Israeli/Palestinian conflict

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
from that in Northern Ireland,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
or the civil war in Sudan

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
from that in Liberia?

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Both successes and failures

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
teach us several critically important things

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
that we need to bear in mind

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
if we want the good news to continue.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
First, leadership.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
In the same way in which ethnic conflict and civil war

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
are not natural

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
but man-made disasters,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
their prevention and settlement

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
does not happen automatically either.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Leadership needs to be capable,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
determined and visionary

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
in its commitment to peace.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Leaders need to connect to each other

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and to their followers,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and they need to bring them along

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
on what is an often arduous journey

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
into a peaceful future.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Second, diplomacy.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Diplomacy needs to be well resourced,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
sustained,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
and apply the right mix of incentives and pressures

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
on leaders and followers.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
It needs to help them reach an equitable compromise,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and it needs to ensure

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
that a broad coalition

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
of local, regional

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
and international supporters

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
help them implement their agreement.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Third, institutional design.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Institutional design requires

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
a keen focus on issues,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
innovative thinking

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and flexible and well-funded implementation.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Conflict parties need to move away

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
from maximum demands

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
and towards a compromise

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
that recognizes each other's needs.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And they need to think

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
about the substance of their agreement

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
much more than about

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
the labels they want to attach to them.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
Conflict parties also need to be prepared

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
to return to the negotiation table

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
if the agreement implementation stalls.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
For me personally,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
the most critical lesson of all is this:

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Local commitment to peace

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
is all-important,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
but it is often not enough

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
to prevent or end violence.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
Yet, no amount of diplomacy

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
or institutional design

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
can make up for local failures

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
and the consequences that they have.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Therefore, we must invest

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
in developing leaders,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
leaders that have the skills,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
vision and determination

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
to make peace.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Leaders, in other words,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
that people will trust

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
and that they will want to follow

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
even if that means

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
making hard choices.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
A final thought:

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
Ending civil wars

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
is a process that is fraught with dangers,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
frustrations and setbacks.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
It often takes a generation to accomplish,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
but it also requires us, today's generation,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
to take responsibility

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
and to learn the right lessons

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
about leadership, diplomacy

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
and institutional design,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
so that the child soldiers of today

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
can become the children of tomorrow.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Thank you.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
(Applause)

title: America's native prisoners of war
transcript: I'm here today to show my photographs of the Lakota. Many of you may have heard of the Lakota, or at least the larger group of tribes, called the Sioux. The Lakota are one of many tribes that were moved off their land to prisoner-of-war camps, now called reservations. The Pine Ridge Reservation, the subject of today's slide show, is located about 75 miles southeast of the Black Hills in South Dakota. It is sometimes referred to as Prisoner of War Camp Number 334, and it is where the Lakota now live. Now, if any of you have ever heard of AIM, the American Indian Movement, or of Russell Means, or Leonard Peltier, or of the standoff at Oglala, then you know Pine Ridge is ground zero for Native issues in the US.So I've been asked to talk a little bit today about my relationship with the Lakota, and that's a very difficult one for me, because, if you haven't noticed from my skin color, I'm white, and that is a huge barrier on a Native reservation. You'll see a lot of people in my photographs today. I've become very close with them, and they've welcomed me like family. They've called me "brother" and "uncle," and invited me again and again over five years. But on Pine Ridge, I will always be what is called "wasichu." "Wasichu" is a Lakota word that means "non-Indian," but another version of this word means "the one who takes the best meat for himself." And that's what I want to focus on — the one who takes the best part of the meat. It means "greedy."So take a look around this auditorium today. We are at a private school in the American West, sitting in red velvet chairs with money in our pockets. And if we look at our lives, we have indeed taken the best part of the meat. So let's look today at a set of photographs of a people who lost so that we could gain, and know that when you see these people's faces, that these are not just images of the Lakota; they stand for all indigenous people.On this piece of paper is the history the way I learned it from my Lakota friends and family. The following is a time line of treaties made, treaties broken and massacres disguised as battles. I'll begin in 1824. What is known as the Bureau of Indian Affairs was created within the War Department, setting an early tone of aggression in our dealings with the Native Americans.1851: The first treaty of Fort Laramie was made, clearly marking the boundaries of the Lakota Nation. According to the treaty, those lands are a sovereign nation. If the boundaries of this treaty had held — and there is a legal basis that they should — then this is what the US would look like today. Ten years later. The Homestead Act, signed by President Lincoln, unleashed a flood of white settlers into Native lands.1863: An uprising of Santee Sioux in Minnesota ends with the hanging of 38 Sioux men, the largest mass execution in US history. The execution was ordered by President Lincoln, only two days after he signed the Emancipation Proclamation.1866: The beginning of the Transcontinental Railroad — a new era. We appropriated land for trails and trains to shortcut through the heart of the Lakota Nation. The treaties were out the window. In response, three tribes led by the Lakota chief Red Cloud attacked and defeated the US army, many times over. I want to repeat that part: The Lakota defeat the US army.1868: The second Fort Laramie Treaty clearly guarantees the sovereignty of the Great Sioux Nation and the Lakotas' ownership of the sacred Black Hills. The government also promises land and hunting rights in the surrounding states. We promise that the Powder River country will henceforth be closed to all whites. The treaty seemed to be a complete victory for Red Cloud and the Sioux. In fact, this is the only war in American history in which the government negotiated a peace by conceding everything demanded by the enemy.1869: The Transcontinental Railroad was completed. It began carrying, among other things, large numbers of hunters, who began the wholesale killing of buffalo, eliminating a source of food, clothing and shelter for the Sioux.1871: The Indian Appropriation Act makes all Indians wards of the federal government. In addition, the military issued orders forbidding western Indians from leaving reservations. All western Indians at that point in time were now prisoners of war. Also in 1871, we ended the time of treaty-making. The problem with treaties is they allow tribes to exist as sovereign nations, and we can't have that. We had plans.1874: General George Custer announced the discovery of gold in Lakota territory, specifically the Black Hills. The news of gold creates a massive influx of white settlers into Lakota Nation. Custer recommends that Congress find a way to end the treaties with the Lakota as soon as possible.1875: The Lakota war begins over the violation of the Fort Laramie Treaty. 1876: On July 26th, on its way to attack a Lakota village, Custer's 7th Cavalry was crushed at the battle of Little Big Horn. 1877: The great Lakota warrior and chief named Crazy Horse surrendered at Fort Robinson. He was later killed while in custody. 1877 is also the year we found a way to get around the Fort Laramie Treaties. A new agreement was presented to Sioux chiefs and their leading men, under a campaign known as "Sell or Starve" — sign the paper, or no food for your tribe. Only 10 percent of the adult male population signed. The Fort Laramie Treaty called for at least three-quarters of the tribe to sign away land. That clause was obviously ignored.1887: The Dawes Act. Communal ownership of reservation lands ends. Reservations are cut up into 160-acre sections, and distributed to individual Indians with the surplus disposed of. Tribes lost millions of acres. The American dream of individual land ownership turned out to be a very clever way to divide the reservation until nothing was left. The move destroyed the reservations, making it easier to further subdivide and to sell with every passing generation. Most of the surplus land and many of the plots within reservation boundaries are now in the hands of white ranchers. Once again, the fat of the land goes to wasichu.1890: A date I believe to be the most important in this slide show. This is the year of the Wounded Knee Massacre. On December 29, US troops surrounded a Sioux encampment at Wounded Knee Creek, and massacred Chief Big Foot and 300 prisoners of war, using a new rapid-fire weapon that fired exploding shells, called a Hotchkiss gun. For this so-called "battle," 20 Congressional Medals of Honor for Valor were given to the 7th Cavalry. To this day, this is the most Medals of Honor ever awarded for a single battle. More Medals of Honor were given for the indiscriminate slaughter of women and children than for any battle in World War One, World War Two, Korea, Vietnam, Iraq or Afghanistan.The Wounded Knee Massacre is considered the end of the Indian wars. Whenever I visit the site of the mass grave at Wounded Knee, I see it not just as a grave for the Lakota or for the Sioux, but as a grave for all indigenous peoples. The holy man Black Elk, said, "I did not know then how much was ended. When I look back now from this high hill of my old age, I can still see the butchered women and children lying heaped and scattered all along the crooked gulch, as plain as when I saw them with eyes still young. And I can see that something else died there in the bloody mud and was buried in the blizzard. A people's dream died there. And it was a beautiful dream."With this event, a new era in Native American history began. Everything can be measured before Wounded Knee and after, because it was in this moment, with the fingers on the triggers of the Hotchkiss guns, that the US government openly declared its position on Native rights. They were tired of treaties. They were tired of sacred hills. They were tired of ghost dances. And they were tired of all the inconveniences of the Sioux. So they brought out their cannons. "You want to be an Indian now?" they said, finger on the trigger.1900: the US Indian population reached its low point — less than 250,000, compared to an estimated eight million in 1492.Fast-forward. 1980: The longest-running court case in US history, the Sioux Nation versus the United States, was ruled upon by the US Supreme Court. The court determined that when the Sioux were resettled onto reservations and seven million acres of their land were opened up to prospectors and homesteaders, the terms of the second Fort Laramie Treaty had been violated. The court stated that the Black Hills were illegally taken, and that the initial offering price, plus interest, should be paid to the Sioux Nation. As payment for the Black Hills, the court awarded only 106 million dollars to the Sioux Nation. The Sioux refused the money with the rallying cry, "The Black Hills are not for sale."2010: Statistics about Native population today, more than a century after the massacre at Wounded Knee, reveal the legacy of colonization, forced migration and treaty violations. Unemployment on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation fluctuates between 85 and 90 percent. The housing office is unable to build new structures, and existing structures are falling apart. Many are homeless, and those with homes are packed into rotting buildings with up to five families. Thirty-nine percent of homes on Pine Ridge have no electricity. At least 60 percent of the homes on the reservation are infested with black mold. More than 90 percent of the population lives below the federal poverty line. The tuberculosis rate on Pine Ridge is approximately eight times higher than the US national average. The infant mortality rate is the highest on this continent, and is about three times higher than the US national average. Cervical cancer is five times higher than the US national average. The school dropout rate is up to 70 percent. Teacher turnover is eight times higher than the US national average. Frequently, grandparents are raising their grandchildren because parents, due to alcoholism, domestic violence and general apathy, cannot raise them. Fifty percent of the population over the age of 40 suffers from diabetes. The life expectancy for men is between 46 and 48 years old — roughly the same as in Afghanistan and Somalia.The last chapter in any successful genocide is the one in which the oppressor can remove their hands and say, "My god — what are these people doing to themselves? They're killing each other. They're killing themselves while we watch them die." This is how we came to own these United States. This is the legacy of Manifest Destiny. Prisoners are still born into prisoner of war camps, long after the guards are gone. These are the bones left after the best meat has been taken.A long time ago, a series of events was set in motion by a people who look like me, by wasichu, eager to take the land and the water and the gold in the hills. Those events led to a domino effect that has yet to end.As removed as we, the dominant society, may feel from a massacre in 1890, or a series of broken treaties 150 years ago, I still have to ask you the question: How should you feel about the statistics of today? What is the connection between these images of suffering and the history that I just read to you? And how much of this history do you need to own, even? Is any of this your responsibility today? I have been told that there must be something we can do. There must be some call to action. Because for so long, I've been standing on the sidelines, content to be a witness, just taking photographs. Because the solutions seem so far in the past, I needed nothing short of a time machine to access them.The suffering of indigenous peoples is not a simple issue to fix. It's not something everyone can get behind the way they get behind helping Haiti, or ending AIDS, or fighting a famine. The "fix," as it's called, may be much more difficult for the dominant society than, say, a $50 check or a church trip to paint some graffiti-covered houses, or a suburban family donating a box of clothes they don't even want anymore. So where does that leave us? Shrugging our shoulders in the dark?The United States continues on a daily basis to violate the terms of the 1851 and 1868 Fort Laramie Treaties with the Lakota. The call to action I offer today — my TED wish — is this: Honor the treaties. Give back the Black Hills. It's not your business what they do with them.(Applause)

00:05:02.332 --> 00:05:04.309

00:05:04.333 --> 00:05:08.025

00:05:08.049 --> 00:05:09.219

00:05:09.243 --> 00:05:10.440
We had plans.

00:05:11.512 --> 00:05:12.735

00:05:12.759 --> 00:05:16.315

00:05:16.339 --> 00:05:18.024

00:05:18.048 --> 00:05:20.859

00:05:20.883 --> 00:05:22.068
into Lakota Nation.

00:05:22.672 --> 00:05:24.705

00:05:24.729 --> 00:05:27.649

00:05:28.006 --> 00:05:31.039

00:05:31.063 --> 00:05:33.715

00:05:34.509 --> 00:05:35.710

00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:37.938

00:05:37.962 --> 00:05:40.181

00:05:40.205 --> 00:05:42.269

00:05:46.543 --> 00:05:49.587

and chief named Crazy Horse

00:05:49.611 --> 00:05:51.334

00:05:51.801 --> 00:05:53.817

00:06:05.922 --> 00:06:08.334

as "Sell or Starve" --

00:06:08.358 --> 00:06:10.663
sign the paper, or no food for your tribe.

male population signed.

00:06:14.544 --> 00:06:18.263
The Fort Laramie Treaty called
for at least three-quarters of the tribe

00:06:18.287 --> 00:06:19.446
to sign away land.

00:06:20.212 --> 00:06:22.040
That clause was obviously ignored.

00:06:22.667 --> 00:06:25.219

00:06:25.769 --> 00:06:28.334
Communal ownership
of reservation lands ends.

00:06:28.358 --> 00:06:31.449
Reservations are cut up
into 160-acre sections,

00:06:31.473 --> 00:06:33.454
and distributed to individual Indians

00:06:33.478 --> 00:06:35.334
with the surplus disposed of.

00:06:35.358 --> 00:06:37.177
Tribes lost millions of acres.

00:06:38.280 --> 00:06:40.527
The American dream
of individual land ownership

00:06:40.551 --> 00:06:42.546
turned out to be a very clever way

00:06:42.570 --> 00:06:45.492
to divide the reservation
until nothing was left.

00:06:45.999 --> 00:06:47.845
The move destroyed the reservations,

00:06:47.869 --> 00:06:50.819

00:06:50.843 --> 00:06:52.764
