00:06:53.113 --> 00:06:54.828
Most of the surplus land

00:06:54.852 --> 00:06:57.488
and many of the plots
within reservation boundaries

00:06:57.512 --> 00:06:59.478
are now in the hands of white ranchers.

00:06:59.992 --> 00:07:03.165
Once again, the fat of the land
goes to wasichu.

00:07:04.119 --> 00:07:08.745
1890: A date I believe to be
the most important in this slide show.

00:07:09.126 --> 00:07:11.549
This is the year
of the Wounded Knee Massacre.

00:07:12.195 --> 00:07:13.616
On December 29,

00:07:13.640 --> 00:07:16.822
US troops surrounded a Sioux
encampment at Wounded Knee Creek,

00:07:16.846 --> 00:07:20.895
and massacred Chief Big Foot
and 300 prisoners of war,

00:07:20.919 --> 00:07:24.421
using a new rapid-fire weapon
that fired exploding shells,

00:07:24.445 --> 00:07:25.603
called a Hotchkiss gun.

00:07:26.508 --> 00:07:28.088
For this so-called "battle,"

00:07:28.112 --> 00:07:31.115
20 Congressional Medals of Honor for Valor

00:07:31.139 --> 00:07:32.971
were given to the 7th Cavalry.

00:07:34.358 --> 00:07:35.661
To this day,

00:07:36.963 --> 00:07:41.071
this is the most Medals of Honor
ever awarded for a single battle.

00:07:41.977 --> 00:07:43.597
More Medals of Honor were given

00:07:43.621 --> 00:07:46.151
for the indiscriminate slaughter
of women and children

00:07:46.175 --> 00:07:49.047
than for any battle in World War One,

00:07:49.071 --> 00:07:50.412
World War Two,

00:07:50.436 --> 00:07:52.747
Korea, Vietnam,

00:07:52.771 --> 00:07:54.848
Iraq or Afghanistan.

00:07:56.769 --> 00:08:00.437
The Wounded Knee Massacre
is considered the end of the Indian wars.

00:08:01.800 --> 00:08:05.260
Whenever I visit the site
of the mass grave at Wounded Knee,

00:08:05.284 --> 00:08:09.686
I see it not just as a grave
for the Lakota or for the Sioux,

00:08:09.710 --> 00:08:12.101
but as a grave for all indigenous peoples.

00:08:15.188 --> 00:08:17.728
The holy man Black Elk, said,

00:08:17.752 --> 00:08:20.145
"I did not know then how much was ended.

00:08:21.695 --> 00:08:25.112
When I look back now
from this high hill of my old age,

00:08:25.136 --> 00:08:27.717
I can still see
the butchered women and children

00:08:27.741 --> 00:08:31.812
lying heaped and scattered
all along the crooked gulch,

00:08:35.709 --> 00:08:37.644
as plain as when I saw them

00:08:37.668 --> 00:08:39.105
with eyes still young.

00:08:42.960 --> 00:08:46.275
And I can see that something else
died there in the bloody mud

00:08:47.933 --> 00:08:49.629
and was buried in the blizzard.

00:08:51.341 --> 00:08:53.298
A people's dream died there.

00:08:54.481 --> 00:08:56.290
And it was a beautiful dream."

00:08:59.036 --> 00:09:00.492
With this event,

00:09:00.516 --> 00:09:03.516
a new era in Native American
history began.

00:09:04.358 --> 00:09:09.334
Everything can be measured
before Wounded Knee and after,

00:09:09.358 --> 00:09:11.125
because it was in this moment,

00:09:11.149 --> 00:09:14.436
with the fingers on the triggers
of the Hotchkiss guns,

00:09:14.460 --> 00:09:18.334
that the US government openly
declared its position on Native rights.

00:09:18.817 --> 00:09:20.334
They were tired of treaties.

00:09:20.753 --> 00:09:22.721
They were tired of sacred hills.

00:09:22.745 --> 00:09:24.578
They were tired of ghost dances.

00:09:25.634 --> 00:09:28.649
And they were tired of all
the inconveniences of the Sioux.

00:09:29.253 --> 00:09:30.888
So they brought out their cannons.

00:09:32.671 --> 00:09:34.998
"You want to be an Indian now?" they said,

00:09:35.022 --> 00:09:36.284
finger on the trigger.

00:09:42.514 --> 00:09:43.680
1900:

00:09:44.506 --> 00:09:47.976
the US Indian population
reached its low point --

00:09:48.000 --> 00:09:50.532
less than 250,000,

00:09:50.556 --> 00:09:54.358
compared to an estimated
eight million in 1492.

00:09:56.454 --> 00:09:57.637
Fast-forward.

00:09:58.358 --> 00:09:59.565
1980:

00:10:00.191 --> 00:10:02.890
The longest-running
court case in US history,

00:10:02.914 --> 00:10:05.495
the Sioux Nation versus the United States,

00:10:05.519 --> 00:10:08.185
was ruled upon by the US Supreme Court.

00:10:09.231 --> 00:10:12.754
The court determined that when the Sioux
were resettled onto reservations

00:10:12.778 --> 00:10:15.865
and seven million acres
of their land were opened up

00:10:15.889 --> 00:10:17.939
to prospectors and homesteaders,

00:10:17.963 --> 00:10:20.526
the terms of the second
Fort Laramie Treaty

00:10:20.550 --> 00:10:21.757
had been violated.

00:10:22.490 --> 00:10:26.230
The court stated that the Black Hills
were illegally taken,

00:10:26.254 --> 00:10:28.869
and that the initial
offering price, plus interest,

00:10:28.893 --> 00:10:30.687
should be paid to the Sioux Nation.

00:10:31.258 --> 00:10:32.810
As payment for the Black Hills,

00:10:32.834 --> 00:10:37.266
the court awarded only 106 million dollars
to the Sioux Nation.

00:10:37.290 --> 00:10:40.334
The Sioux refused the money
with the rallying cry,

00:10:40.358 --> 00:10:42.334
"The Black Hills are not for sale."

00:10:43.588 --> 00:10:44.747
2010:

00:10:45.287 --> 00:10:48.079
Statistics about Native population today,

00:10:48.103 --> 00:10:51.334
more than a century
after the massacre at Wounded Knee,

00:10:51.358 --> 00:10:53.943
reveal the legacy of colonization,

00:10:53.967 --> 00:10:55.235
forced migration

00:10:55.259 --> 00:10:56.702
and treaty violations.

00:10:57.853 --> 00:11:00.283
Unemployment on the Pine Ridge
Indian Reservation

00:11:00.307 --> 00:11:02.885
fluctuates between 85 and 90 percent.

00:11:03.647 --> 00:11:06.496
The housing office is unable
to build new structures,

00:11:06.520 --> 00:11:08.656
and existing structures are falling apart.

00:11:08.988 --> 00:11:10.157
Many are homeless,

00:11:10.181 --> 00:11:12.740
and those with homes
are packed into rotting buildings

00:11:12.764 --> 00:11:14.109
with up to five families.

00:11:14.556 --> 00:11:16.763
Thirty-nine percent of homes on Pine Ridge

00:11:16.787 --> 00:11:18.024
have no electricity.

00:11:18.482 --> 00:11:21.151
At least 60 percent
of the homes on the reservation

00:11:21.175 --> 00:11:22.992
are infested with black mold.

00:11:23.698 --> 00:11:27.963
More than 90 percent of the population
lives below the federal poverty line.

00:11:28.772 --> 00:11:30.932
The tuberculosis rate on Pine Ridge

00:11:30.956 --> 00:11:34.147
is approximately eight times higher
than the US national average.

00:11:34.573 --> 00:11:37.803
The infant mortality rate
is the highest on this continent,

00:11:37.827 --> 00:11:41.135
and is about three times higher
than the US national average.

00:11:41.159 --> 00:11:43.554
Cervical cancer is five times higher

00:11:43.578 --> 00:11:45.389
than the US national average.

00:11:45.413 --> 00:11:48.166
The school dropout rate
is up to 70 percent.

00:11:48.757 --> 00:11:52.862
Teacher turnover is eight times higher
than the US national average.

00:11:53.358 --> 00:11:56.727
Frequently, grandparents
are raising their grandchildren

00:11:56.751 --> 00:11:59.069
because parents, due to alcoholism,

00:11:59.093 --> 00:12:01.818
domestic violence and general apathy,

00:12:01.842 --> 00:12:03.040
cannot raise them.

00:12:04.040 --> 00:12:07.111
Fifty percent of the population
over the age of 40

00:12:07.135 --> 00:12:08.611
suffers from diabetes.

00:12:09.592 --> 00:12:15.461
The life expectancy for men
is between 46 and 48 years old --

00:12:16.223 --> 00:12:20.226
roughly the same
as in Afghanistan and Somalia.

00:12:22.096 --> 00:12:25.636
The last chapter
in any successful genocide

00:12:25.660 --> 00:12:27.637
is the one in which the oppressor

00:12:27.661 --> 00:12:30.201
can remove their hands and say,

00:12:30.225 --> 00:12:33.687
"My god -- what are these people
doing to themselves?

00:12:33.711 --> 00:12:35.407
They're killing each other.

00:12:35.431 --> 00:12:37.334
They're killing themselves

00:12:37.358 --> 00:12:39.007
while we watch them die."

00:12:40.199 --> 00:12:43.175
This is how we came to own
these United States.

00:12:43.658 --> 00:12:44.952
This is the legacy

00:12:44.977 --> 00:12:46.603
of Manifest Destiny.

00:12:47.411 --> 00:12:51.638
Prisoners are still born
into prisoner of war camps,

00:12:51.662 --> 00:12:53.624
long after the guards are gone.

00:12:56.407 --> 00:13:01.050
These are the bones
left after the best meat has been taken.

00:13:03.849 --> 00:13:05.167
A long time ago,

00:13:05.191 --> 00:13:07.168
a series of events was set in motion

00:13:07.192 --> 00:13:10.694
by a people who look like me, by wasichu,

00:13:10.718 --> 00:13:14.177
eager to take the land and the water
and the gold in the hills.

00:13:15.160 --> 00:13:18.244
Those events led to a domino effect
that has yet to end.

00:13:19.286 --> 00:13:22.725
As removed as we,
the dominant society, may feel

00:13:24.112 --> 00:13:26.705
from a massacre in 1890,

00:13:26.729 --> 00:13:30.455
or a series of broken
treaties 150 years ago,

00:13:30.929 --> 00:13:33.090
I still have to ask you the question:

00:13:34.042 --> 00:13:36.669
How should you feel
about the statistics of today?

00:13:37.836 --> 00:13:41.000
What is the connection
between these images of suffering

00:13:41.024 --> 00:13:43.000
and the history that I just read to you?

00:13:43.888 --> 00:13:46.738
And how much of this history
do you need to own, even?

00:13:47.437 --> 00:13:49.688
Is any of this your responsibility today?

00:13:51.231 --> 00:13:53.924
I have been told that there must be
something we can do.

00:13:53.948 --> 00:13:56.374
There must be some call to action.

00:13:57.655 --> 00:14:00.730
Because for so long,
I've been standing on the sidelines,

00:14:01.167 --> 00:14:02.793
content to be a witness,

00:14:02.817 --> 00:14:04.681
just taking photographs.

00:14:05.619 --> 00:14:08.218
Because the solutions
seem so far in the past,

00:14:08.242 --> 00:14:11.575
I needed nothing short
of a time machine to access them.

00:14:12.638 --> 00:14:17.746
The suffering of indigenous peoples
is not a simple issue to fix.

00:14:18.598 --> 00:14:20.614
It's not something everyone can get behind

00:14:20.638 --> 00:14:22.487
the way they get behind helping Haiti,

00:14:22.511 --> 00:14:24.914
or ending AIDS, or fighting a famine.

00:14:25.697 --> 00:14:27.663
The "fix," as it's called,

00:14:27.687 --> 00:14:30.334
may be much more difficult
for the dominant society

00:14:30.358 --> 00:14:32.655
than, say, a $50 check

00:14:32.679 --> 00:14:35.976
or a church trip to paint
some graffiti-covered houses,

00:14:36.000 --> 00:14:37.611
or a suburban family

00:14:37.635 --> 00:14:40.611
donating a box of clothes
they don't even want anymore.

00:14:41.254 --> 00:14:42.649
So where does that leave us?

00:14:43.134 --> 00:14:45.198
Shrugging our shoulders in the dark?

00:14:46.968 --> 00:14:51.648
The United States continues
on a daily basis to violate the terms

00:14:51.672 --> 00:14:56.121
of the 1851 and 1868
Fort Laramie Treaties with the Lakota.

00:14:56.681 --> 00:14:59.013
The call to action I offer today --

00:14:59.850 --> 00:15:01.899
my TED wish -- is this:

00:15:03.309 --> 00:15:04.590
Honor the treaties.

00:15:05.183 --> 00:15:06.880
Give back the Black Hills.

00:15:07.277 --> 00:15:09.519
It's not your business
what they do with them.

00:15:11.856 --> 00:15:18.735
(Applause)

title: Making global labor fair
transcript: This cell phone started its trajectory in an artisanal mine in the Eastern Congo. It's mined by armed gangs using slaves, child slaves, what the U.N. Security Council calls "blood minerals," then traveled into some components and ended up in a factory in Shinjin in China. That factory — over a dozen people have committed suicide already this year. One man died after working a 36-hour shift. We all love chocolate. We buy it for our kids. Eighty percent of the cocoa comes from Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana and it's harvested by children. Cote d'Ivoire, we have a huge problem of child slaves. Children have been trafficked from other conflict zones to come and work on the coffee plantations. Heparin — a blood thinner, a pharmaceutical product — starts out in artisanal workshops like this in China, because the active ingredient comes from pigs' intestines. Your diamond — you've all heard, probably seen the movie "Blood Diamond." This is a mine in Zimbabwe right now. Cotton: Uzbekistan is the second biggest exporter of cotton on Earth. Every year when it comes to the cotton harvest, the government shuts down the schools, puts the kids in buses, buses them to the cotton fields to spend three weeks harvesting the cotton. It's forced child labor on an institutional scale. And all of those products probably end their lives in a dump like this one in Manila.These places, these origins, represent governance gaps. That's the politest description I have for them. These are the dark pools where global supply chains begin — the global supply chains, which bring us our favorite brand name products. Some of these governance gaps are run by rogue states. Some of them are not states anymore at all. They're failed states. Some of them are just countries who believe that deregulation or no regulation is the best way to attract investment, promote trade. Either way, they present us with a huge moral and ethical dilemma. I know that none of us want to be accessories after the fact of a human rights abuse in a global supply chain. But right now, most of the companies involved in these supply chains don't have any way of assuring us that nobody had to mortgage their future, nobody had to sacrifice their rights to bring us our favorite brand name product.Now, I didn't come here to depress you about the state of the global supply chain. We need a reality check. We need to recognize just how serious a deficit of rights we have. This is an independent republic, probably a failed state. It's definitely not a democratic state. And right now, that independent republic of the supply chain is not being governed in a way that would satisfy us, that we can engage in ethical trade or ethical consumption. Now, that's not a new story. You've seen the documentaries of sweatshops making garments all over the world, even in developed countries. You want to see the classic sweatshop, meet me at Madison Square Garden, I'll take you down the street, and I'll show you a Chinese sweatshop.But take the example of heparin. It's a pharmaceutical product. You expect that the supply chain that gets it to the hospital, probably squeaky clean. The problem is that the active ingredient in there — as I mentioned earlier — comes from pigs. The main American manufacturer of that active ingredient decided a few years ago to relocate to China because it's the world's biggest supplier of pigs. And their factory in China — which probably is pretty clean — is getting all of the ingredients from backyard abattoirs, where families slaughter pigs and extract the ingredient. So a couple of years ago, we had a scandal which killed about 80 people around the world, because of contaminants that crept into the heparin supply chain. Worse, some of the suppliers realized that they could substitute a product which mimicked heparin in tests. This substitute cost nine dollars a pound, whereas real heparin, the real ingredient, cost 900 dollars a pound. A no-brainer. The problem was that it killed more people.And so you're asking yourself, "How come the U.S. Food and Drug Administration allowed this to happen? How did the Chinese State Agency for Food and Drugs allow this to happen?" And the answer is quite simple: the Chinese define these facilities as chemical facilities, not pharmaceutical facilities, so they don't audit them. And the USFDA has a jurisdictional problem. This is offshore. They actually do conduct a few investigations overseas — about a dozen a year — maybe 20 in a good year. There are 500 of these facilities producing active ingredients in China alone. In fact, about 80 percent of the active ingredients in medicines now come from offshore, particularly China and India, and we don't have a governance system. We don't have a regulatory system able to ensure that that production is safe. We don't have a system to ensure that human rights, basic dignity, are ensured.So at a national level — and we work in about 60 different countries — at a national level we've got a serious breakdown in the ability of governments to regulate production on their own soil. And the real problem with the global supply chain is that it's supranational. So governments who are failing, who are dropping the ball at a national level, have even less ability to get their arms around the problem at an international level. And you can just look at the headlines. Take Copenhagen last year — complete failure of governments to do the right thing in the face of an international challenge. Take the G20 meeting a couple of weeks ago — stepped back from its commitments of just a few months ago. You can take any one of the major global challenges we've discussed this week and ask yourself, where is the leadership from governments to step up and come up with solutions, responses, to those international problems? And the simple answer is they can't. They're national. Their voters are local. They have parochial interests. They can't subordinate those interests to the greater global public good.So, if we're going to ensure the delivery of the key public goods at an international level — in this case, in the global supply chain — we have to come up with a different mechanism. We need a different machine. Fortunately, we have some examples. In the 1990s, there were a whole series of scandals concerning the production of brand name goods in the U.S. — child labor, forced labor, serious health and safety abuses. And eventually President Clinton, in 1996, convened a meeting at the White House, invited industry, human rights NGOs, trade unions, the Department of Labor, got them all in a room and said, "Look, I don't want globalization to be a race to the bottom. I don't know how to prevent that, but I'm at least going to use my good offices to get you folks together to come up with a response." So they formed a White House task force, and they spent about three years arguing about who takes how much responsibility in the global supply chain. Companies didn't feel it was their responsibility. They don't own those facilities. They don't employ those workers. They're not legally liable. Everybody else at the table said, "Folks, that doesn't cut it. You have a custodial duty, a duty of care, to make sure that that product gets from wherever to the store in a way that allows us to consume it, without fear of our safety, or without having to sacrifice our conscience to consume that product." So they agreed, "Okay, what we'll do is we agree on a common set of standards, code of conduct. We'll apply that throughout our global supply chain regardless of ownership or control. We'll make it part of the contract." And that was a stroke of absolute genius, because what they did was they harnessed the power of the contract, private power, to deliver public goods.And let's face it, the contract from a major multinational brand to a supplier in India or China has much more persuasive value than the local labor law, the local environmental regulations, the local human rights standards. Those factories will probably never see an inspector. If the inspector did come along, it would be amazing if they were able to resist the bribe. Even if they did their jobs, and they cited those facilities for their violations, the fine would be derisory. But you lose that contract for a major brand name, that's the difference between staying in business or going bankrupt. That makes a difference. So what we've been able to do is we've been able to harness the power and the influence of the only truly transnational institution in the global supply chain, that of the multinational company, and get them to do the right thing, get them to use that power for good, to deliver the key public goods.Now of course, this doesn't come naturally to multinational companies. They weren't set up to do this. They're set up to make money. But they are extremely efficient organizations. They have resources, and if we can add the will, the commitment, they know how to deliver that product. Now, getting there is not easy. Those supply chains I put up on the screen earlier, they're not there. You need a safe space. You need a place where people can come together, sit down without fear of judgment, without recrimination, to actually face the problem, agree on the problem and come up with solutions. We can do it. The technical solutions are there. The problem is the lack of trust, the lack of confidence, the lack of partnership between NGOs, campaign groups, civil society organizations and multinational companies. If we can put those two together in a safe space, get them to work together, we can deliver public goods right now, or in extremely short supply.This is a radical proposition, and it's crazy to think that if you're a 15-year-old Bangladeshi girl leaving your rural village to go and work in a factory in Dhaka — 22, 23, 24 dollars a month — your best chance of enjoying rights at work is if that factory is producing for a brand name company which has got a code of conduct and made that code of conduct part of the contract. It's crazy. Multinationals are protecting human rights. I know there's going to be disbelief. You'll say, "How can we trust them?" Well, we don't. It's the old arms control phrase: "Trust, but verify." So we audit. We take their supply chain, we take all the factory names, we do a random sample, we send inspectors on an unannounced basis to inspect those facilities, and then we publish the results. Transparency is absolutely critical to this. You can call yourself responsible, but responsibility without accountability often doesn't work. So what we're doing is, we're not only enlisting the multinationals, we're giving them the tools to deliver this public good — respect for human rights — and we're checking. You don't need to believe me. You shouldn't believe me. Go to the website. Look at the audit results. Ask yourself, is this company behaving in a socially responsible way? Can I buy that product without compromising my ethics? That's the way the system works.I hate the idea that governments are not protecting human rights around the world. I hate the idea that governments have dropped this ball and I can't get used to the idea that somehow we can't get them to do their jobs. I've been at this for 30 years, and in that time I've seen the ability, the commitment, the will of government to do this decline, and I don't see them making a comeback right now. So we started out thinking this was a stopgap measure. We're now thinking that, in fact, this is probably the start of a new way of regulating and addressing international challenges. Call it network governance. Call it what you will. The private actors, companies and NGOs, are going to have to get together to face the major challenges we are going to face. Just look at pandemics — swine flu, bird flu, H1N1. Look at the health systems in so many countries. Do they have the resources to face up to a serious pandemic? No. Could the private sector and NGOs get together and marshal a response? Absolutely. What they lack is that safe space to come together, agree and move to action. That's what we're trying to provide.I know as well that this often seems like an overwhelming level of responsibility for people to assume. "You want me to deliver human rights throughout my global supply chain. There are thousands of suppliers in there." It seems too daunting, too dangerous, for any company to take on. But there are companies. We have 4,000 companies who are members. Some of them are very, very large companies. The sporting goods industry, in particular, stepped up to the plate and have done it. The example, the role model, is there. And whenever we discuss one of these problems that we have to address — child labor in cottonseed farms in India — this year we will monitor 50,000 cottonseed farms in India. It seems overwhelming. The numbers just make you want to zone out. But we break it down to some basic realities.And human rights comes down to a very simple proposition: can I give this person their dignity back? Poor people, people whose human rights have been violated — the crux of that is the loss of dignity, the lack of dignity. It starts with just giving people back their dignity. I was sitting in a slum outside Gurgaon just next to Delhi, one of the flashiest, brightest new cities popping up in India right now, and I was talking to workers who worked in garment sweatshops down the road, and I asked them what message they would like me to take to the brands. They didn't say money. They said, "The people who employ us treat us like we are less than human, like we don't exist. Please ask them to treat us like human beings." That's my simple understanding of human rights. That's my simple proposition to you, my simple plea to every decision-maker in this room, everybody out there. We can all make a decision to come together and pick up the balls and run with the balls that governments have dropped. If we don't do it, we're abandoning hope, we're abandoning our essential humanity, and I know that's not a place we want to be, and we don't have to be there. So I appeal to you. Join us, come into that safe space, and let's start to make this happen.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
promote trade.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
Either way, they present us

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
with a huge moral and ethical dilemma.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
I know that none of us want to be accessories

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
after the fact

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
of a human rights abuse

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
in a global supply chain.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
But right now,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
most of the companies involved in these supply chains

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
don't have any way

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
of assuring us

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
that nobody had to mortgage their future,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
nobody had to sacrifice their rights

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
to bring us our favorite

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
brand name product.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
Now, I didn't come here to depress you

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
about the state of the global supply chain.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
We need a reality check.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
We need to recognize just how serious

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
a deficit of rights we have.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
This is an independent republic,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
probably a failed state.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
It's definitely not a democratic state.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And right now,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
that independent republic of the supply chain

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
is not being governed

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
in a way that would satisfy us,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
that we can engage in ethical trade or ethical consumption.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
Now, that's not a new story.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
You've seen the documentaries

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
of sweatshops making garments

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
all over the world, even in developed countries.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
You want to see the classic sweatshop,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
meet me at Madison Square Garden,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
I'll take you down the street, and I'll show you a Chinese sweatshop.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
But take the example of heparin.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
It's a pharmaceutical product.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
You expect that the supply chain that gets it to the hospital,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
probably squeaky clean.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
The problem is that the active ingredient in there --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
as I mentioned earlier --

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
comes from pigs.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
The main American manufacturer

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
of that active ingredient

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
decided a few years ago to relocate to China

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
because it's the world's biggest supplier of pigs.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And their factory in China --

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
which probably is pretty clean --

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
is getting all of the ingredients

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
from backyard abattoirs,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
where families slaughter pigs

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and extract the ingredient.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
So a couple of years ago, we had a scandal

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
which killed about 80 people around the world,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
because of contaminants

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
that crept into the heparin supply chain.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Worse, some of the suppliers

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
realized that they could substitute a product

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
which mimicked heparin in tests.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
This substitute cost nine dollars a pound,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
whereas real heparin, the real ingredient,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
cost 900 dollars a pound.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
A no-brainer.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
The problem was that it killed more people.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And so you're asking yourself,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
"How come the U.S. Food and Drug Administration

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
allowed this to happen?

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
How did the Chinese State Agency for Food and Drugs

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
allow this to happen?"

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And the answer is quite simple:

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
the Chinese define these facilities

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
as chemical facilities, not pharmaceutical facilities,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
so they don't audit them.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
And the USFDA

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
has a jurisdictional problem.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
This is offshore.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
They actually do conduct a few investigations overseas --

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
about a dozen a year -- maybe 20 in a good year.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
There are 500

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
of these facilities

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
producing active ingredients in China alone.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
In fact, about 80 percent

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
of the active ingredients in medicines now

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
come from offshore,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
particularly China and India,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and we don't have a governance system.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
We don't have a regulatory system

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
able to ensure

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
that that production is safe.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
We don't have a system to ensure

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
that human rights, basic dignity,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
are ensured.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So at a national level --

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
and we work in about 60 different countries --

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
at a national level

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
we've got a serious breakdown in the ability of governments

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
to regulate production

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
on their own soil.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
And the real problem with the global supply chain

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
is that it's supranational.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
So governments who are failing,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
who are dropping the ball

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
at a national level,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
have even less ability to get their arms around the problem

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
at an international level.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And you can just look at the headlines.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Take Copenhagen last year --

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
complete failure of governments

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
to do the right thing

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
in the face of an international challenge.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Take the G20 meeting a couple of weeks ago --

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
stepped back from its commitments of just a few months ago.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
You can take any one

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
of the major global challenges we've discussed this week

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and ask yourself, where is the leadership from governments

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
to step up and come up with solutions,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
responses,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
to those international problems?

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And the simple answer is they can't. They're national.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Their voters are local.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
They have parochial interests.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
They can't subordinate those interests

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
to the greater global public good.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
So, if we're going to ensure the delivery

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
of the key public goods

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
at an international level --

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
in this case, in the global supply chain --

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
we have to come up with a different mechanism.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
We need a different machine.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Fortunately, we have some examples.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
In the 1990s,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
there were a whole series of scandals

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
concerning the production of brand name goods in the U.S. --

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
child labor, forced labor,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
serious health and safety abuses.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And eventually President Clinton, in 1996,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
convened a meeting at the White House,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
invited industry, human rights NGOs,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
trade unions, the Department of Labor,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
got them all in a room

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
and said, "Look,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
I don't want globalization to be a race to the bottom.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
I don't know how to prevent that,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
but I'm at least going to use my good offices

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
to get you folks together

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
to come up with a response."

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
So they formed a White House task force,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and they spent about three years arguing

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
about who takes how much responsibility

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
in the global supply chain.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
Companies didn't feel it was their responsibility.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
They don't own those facilities.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
They don't employ those workers.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
They're not legally liable.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Everybody else at the table

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
said, "Folks, that doesn't cut it.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
You have a custodial duty, a duty of care,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
to make sure that that product

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
gets from wherever to the store

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
in a way that allows us to consume it,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
without fear of our safety,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
or without having to sacrifice our conscience

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
to consume that product."

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
So they agreed, "Okay, what we'll do

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
is we agree on a common set of standards,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
code of conduct.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
We'll apply that throughout

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
our global supply chain

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
regardless of ownership or control.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
We'll make it part of the contract."

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And that was a stroke of absolute genius,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
because what they did

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
was they harnessed the power of the contract,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
private power,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
to deliver public goods.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And let's face it,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
the contract from a major multinational brand

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
to a supplier in India or China

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
has much more persuasive value

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
than the local labor law,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
the local environmental regulations,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
the local human rights standards.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Those factories will probably never see an inspector.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
If the inspector did come along,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
it would be amazing if they were able

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
to resist the bribe.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Even if they did their jobs,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and they cited those facilities for their violations,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
the fine would be derisory.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
But you lose that contract

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
for a major brand name,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
that's the difference

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
between staying in business or going bankrupt.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
That makes a difference.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
So what we've been able to do

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
is we've been able to harness

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
the power and the influence

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
of the only truly transnational institution

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
in the global supply chain,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that of the multinational company,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and get them to do the right thing,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
get them to use that power for good,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
to deliver the key public goods.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Now of course, this doesn't come naturally

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
to multinational companies.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
They weren't set up to do this. They're set up to make money.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
But they are extremely efficient organizations.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
They have resources,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and if we can add the will, the commitment,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
they know how to deliver that product.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
Now, getting there is not easy.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Those supply chains I put up on the screen earlier,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
they're not there.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
You need a safe space.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
You need a place where people can come together,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
sit down without fear of judgment,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
without recrimination,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
to actually face the problem,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
agree on the problem and come up with solutions.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
We can do it. The technical solutions are there.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
The problem is the lack of trust, the lack of confidence,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
the lack of partnership

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
between NGOs, campaign groups,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
civil society organizations

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and multinational companies.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
If we can put those two together in a safe space,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
get them to work together,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
we can deliver public goods right now,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
or in extremely short supply.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
This is a radical proposition,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
and it's crazy to think

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
that if you're a 15-year-old Bangladeshi girl

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
leaving your rural village

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
to go and work in a factory in Dhaka --

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
22, 23, 24 dollars a month --

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
your best chance of enjoying rights at work

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
is if that factory is producing

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
for a brand name company

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
which has got a code of conduct

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and made that code of conduct part of the contract.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
It's crazy.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Multinationals are protecting human rights.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
I know there's going to be disbelief.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
You'll say, "How can we trust them?"

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Well, we don't.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
It's the old arms control phrase:

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
"Trust, but verify."

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
So we audit.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
We take their supply chain, we take all the factory names,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
we do a random sample,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
we send inspectors on an unannounced basis

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
to inspect those facilities,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
and then we publish the results.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
Transparency is absolutely critical to this.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
You can call yourself responsible,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
but responsibility without accountability

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
often doesn't work.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So what we're doing is, we're not only enlisting the multinationals,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
we're giving them the tools to deliver this public good --

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
respect for human rights --

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and we're checking.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
You don't need to believe me. You shouldn't believe me.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Go to the website. Look at the audit results.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Ask yourself, is this company behaving

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
in a socially responsible way?

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
Can I buy that product

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
without compromising my ethics?

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
That's the way the system works.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
I hate the idea

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
that governments are not protecting human rights around the world.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
I hate the idea

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
that governments have dropped this ball

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and I can't get used to the idea

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
that somehow we can't get them to do their jobs.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
I've been at this for 30 years,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
and in that time I've seen

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
the ability, the commitment, the will of government

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
to do this decline,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
and I don't see them making a comeback right now.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
So we started out thinking

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
this was a stopgap measure.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
We're now thinking that, in fact,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
this is probably the start

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
of a new way of regulating and addressing

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
international challenges.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Call it network governance. Call it what you will.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
The private actors,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
companies and NGOs,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
are going to have to get together

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
to face the major challenges we are going to face.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Just look at pandemics --

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
swine flu, bird flu, H1N1.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
Look at the health systems in so many countries.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Do they have the resources

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
to face up to a serious pandemic?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
No.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
Could the private sector and NGOs

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
get together and marshal a response?

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Absolutely.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
What they lack is that safe space

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
to come together, agree

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
and move to action.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
That's what we're trying to provide.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
I know as well

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
that this often seems

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
like an overwhelming level of responsibility

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
for people to assume.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
"You want me to deliver human rights

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
throughout my global supply chain.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
There are thousands of suppliers in there."

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
It seems too daunting, too dangerous,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
for any company to take on.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
But there are companies.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
We have 4,000 companies who are members.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Some of them are very, very large companies.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
The sporting goods industry, in particular,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
stepped up to the plate and have done it.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
The example, the role model, is there.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And whenever we discuss

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
one of these problems that we have to address --

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
child labor in cottonseed farms in India --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
this year we will monitor 50,000 cottonseed farms in India.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
It seems overwhelming.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
The numbers just make you want to zone out.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
But we break it down to some basic realities.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And human rights

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
comes down to a very simple proposition:

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
can I give this person their dignity back?

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
Poor people,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
people whose human rights have been violated --

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
the crux of that

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
is the loss of dignity,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
the lack of dignity.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
It starts with just giving people back their dignity.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
I was sitting in a slum outside Gurgaon

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
just next to Delhi,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
one of the flashiest, brightest new cities

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
popping up in India right now,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
and I was talking to workers

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
who worked in garment sweatshops down the road,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
and I asked them what message they would like me to take to the brands.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
They didn't say money.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
They said, "The people who employ us

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
treat us like we are less than human,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
like we don't exist.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Please ask them to treat us like human beings."

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
That's my simple understanding of human rights.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
That's my simple proposition to you,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
my simple plea to every decision-maker

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
in this room, everybody out there.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
We can all make a decision

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
to come together

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
and pick up the balls and run with the balls

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
that governments have dropped.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
If we don't do it,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
we're abandoning hope,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:21.958
we're abandoning our essential humanity,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
and I know that's not a place we want to be,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
and we don't have to be there.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
So I appeal to you.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
Join us, come into that safe space,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
and let's start to make this happen.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
(Applause)

title: Simplifying complexity
transcript: Do you ever feel completely overwhelmed when you're faced with a complex problem? Well, I hope to change that in less than three minutes. So, I hope to convince you that complex doesn't always equal complicated. So for me, a well-crafted baguette, fresh out of the oven, is complex, but a curry onion green olive poppy cheese bread is complicated. I'm an ecologist, and I study complexity. I love complexity. And I study that in the natural world, the interconnectedness of species.So here's a food web, or a map of feeding links between species that live in Alpine Lakes in the mountains of California. And this is what happens to that food web when it's stocked with non-native fish that never lived there before. All the grayed-out species disappear. Some are actually on the brink of extinction. And lakes with fish have more mosquitos, even though they eat them. These effects were all unanticipated, and yet we're discovering they're predictable.So I want to share with you a couple key insights about complexity we're learning from studying nature that maybe are applicable to other problems. First is the simple power of good visualization tools to help untangle complexity and just encourage you to ask questions you didn't think of before. For example, you could plot the flow of carbon through corporate supply chains in a corporate ecosystem, or the interconnections of habitat patches for endangered species in Yosemite National Park. The next thing is that if you want to predict the effect of one species on another, if you focus only on that link, and then you black box the rest, it's actually less predictable than if you step back, consider the entire system — all the species, all the links — and from that place, hone in on the sphere of influence that matters most. And we're discovering, with our research, that's often very local to the node you care about within one or two degrees. So the more you step back, embrace complexity, the better chance you have of finding simple answers, and it's often different than the simple answer that you started with.So let's switch gears and look at a really complex problem courtesy of the U.S. government. This is a diagram of the U.S. counterinsurgency strategy in Afghanistan. It was front page of the New York Times a couple months ago. Instantly ridiculed by the media for being so crazy complicated. And the stated goal was to increase popular support for the Afghan government. Clearly a complex problem, but is it complicated? Well, when I saw this in the front page of the Times, I thought, "Great. Finally something I can relate to. I can sink my teeth into this."So let's do it. So here we go for the first time ever, a world premiere view of this spaghetti diagram as an ordered network. The circled node is the one we're trying to influence — popular support for the government. And so now we can look one degrees, two degrees, three degrees away from that node and eliminate three-quarters of the diagram outside that sphere of influence. Within that sphere, most of those nodes are not actionable, like the harshness of the terrain, and a very small minority are actual military actions. Most are non-violent and they fall into two broad categories: active engagement with ethnic rivalries and religious beliefs and fair, transparent economic development and provisioning of services. I don't know about this, but this is what I can decipher from this diagram in 24 seconds.When you see a diagram like this, I don't want you to be afraid. I want you to be excited. I want you to be relieved. Because simple answers may emerge. We're discovering in nature that simplicity often lies on the other side of complexity. So for any problem, the more you can zoom out and embrace complexity, the better chance you have of zooming in on the simple details that matter most.Thank you.(Applause)
