out of the same materials.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
So if this gentleman

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
had had a holistic education,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
would he be sitting there?

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
Would he have had more possibilities in his life?

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
The classrooms have natural light.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
They're beautiful. They're bamboo.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
The breeze passes through them.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
And when the natural breeze isn't enough,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
the kids deploy bubbles,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
but not the kind of bubbles you know.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
These bubbles are made from natural cotton

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
and rubber from the rubber tree.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
So we basically turned the box

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
into a bubble.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And these kids know

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
that painless climate control

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
may not be

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
part of their future.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
We pay the bill at the end of the month,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
but the people that are really going to pay the bill

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
are our grandchildren.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
We have to teach the kids

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
that the world is not indestructible.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
These kids did a little graffiti on their desks,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and then they signed up for two extra courses.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
The first one was called sanding

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
and the second one was called re-waxing.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
But since that happened,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
they own those desks.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
They know they can control their world.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
We're on the grid. We're not proud of it.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
But an amazing alternative energy company in Paris

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
is taking us off the grid with solar.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And this thing

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
is the second vortex to be built in the world,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
in a two-and-a-half meter drop on a river.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
When the turbine drops in,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
it will produce 8,000 watts of electricity,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
day and night.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
And you know what these are.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
There's nowhere to flush.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And as long as we're taking our waste

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
and mixing it with a huge amount of water --

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
you're all really smart, just do the math.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
How many people times how much water.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
There isn't enough water.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
These are compost toilets,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
and nobody at the school wanted to know about them,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
especially the principal.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And they work. People use them. People are okay.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
It's something you should think about doing.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
Not many things didn't work.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
The beautiful canvas and rubber skylights

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
got eaten by the sun in six months.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
We had to replace them with recyclable plastic.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
The teachers dragged giant PVC whiteboards

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
into the classrooms.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
So we had some good ideas:

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
we took old automobile windshields, put paper behind them

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and created the first alternative

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
to the whiteboard.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
Green School sits in south-central Bali,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
and it's on 20 acres

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
of rolling garden.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
There's an amazing river traveling through it,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
and you can see there

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
how we manage to get across the river.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
I met a father the other day; he looked a little crazed.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
I said, "Welcome to Green School."

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
He said, "I've been on an airplane for 24 hours."

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
I asked him, "Why?"

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
He said, "I had a dream once about a green school,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and I saw a picture of this green school,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
I got on an airplane.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
In August I'm bringing my sons."

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
This was a great thing.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
But more than that,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
people are building green houses around Green School,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
so their kids can walk to school on the paths.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
And people are bringing their green industries,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
hopefully their green restaurants,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
to the Green School.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
It's becoming a community.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
It's becoming a green model.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
We had to look at everything.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
No petrochemicals in the pavement.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
No pavement.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
These are volcanic stones laid by hand.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
There are no sidewalks.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
The sidewalks are gravel. They flood when it rains,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
but they're green.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
This is the school buffalo.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
He's planning to eat that fence for dinner.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
All the fences at Green School are green.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And when the kindergarten kids

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
recently moved their gate,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
they found out the fence was made out of tapioca.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
They took the tapioca roots up to the kitchen,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
sliced them thinly and made delicious chips.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Landscaping.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
We manage to keep the garden that was there

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
running right up to the edge of each of the classrooms.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
We dropped them gently in.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
We made space for these guys

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
who are Bali's last black pigs.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And the school cow

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
is trying to figure out

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
how to replace the lawnmower

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
on the playing field.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
These young ladies

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
are living in a rice culture,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
but they know something that few people know in a rice culture.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
They know how to plant organic rice,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
they know how to look after it,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
they know how to harvest and they know how to cook it.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
They're part of the rice cycle

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and these skills will be valuable

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
for them in their future.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
This young man is picking organic vegetables.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
We feed 400 people lunch every day

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and it's not a normal lunch. There's no gas.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Local Balinese women

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
cook the food on sawdust burners

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
using secrets that only their grandmothers know.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
The food is incredible.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
Green School is a place of pioneers,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
local and global.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
And it's a kind of microcosm

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
of the globalized world.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
The kids are from 25 countries.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
When I see them together,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I know that they're working out

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
how to live in the future.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Green School is going into its third year

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
with 160 children.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
It's a school where you do learn reading --

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
one of my favorites --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
writing -- I was bad at it --

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
arithmetic.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
But you also learn other things.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
You learn bamboo building.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
You practice

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
ancient Balinese arts.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
This is called mud wrestling in the rice fields.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
The kids love it.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
The mothers aren't quite convinced.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
(Laughter)

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
We've done a lot of outrageous things in our lives,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
and we said, okay, local, what does "local" mean?

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
Local means

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
that 20 percent of the population of the school

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
has to be Balinese,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
and this was a really big commitment.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And we were right.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
And people are coming forward

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
from all over the world

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
to support the Balinese Scholarship Fund,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
because these kids will be Bali's next green leaders.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
The teachers are as diverse

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
as the student body,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and the amazing thing

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
is that volunteers are popping up.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
A man came from Java

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
with a new kind of organic agriculture.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
A woman came from Africa with music.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And together these volunteers and the teachers

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
are deeply committed

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
to creating a new generation

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
of global, green leaders.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
The Green School effect --

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
we don't know what it is.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We need someone to come and study it.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
But what's happening, our learning-different kids --

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
dyslexic --

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
we've renamed them prolexic --

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
are doing well in these beautiful, beautiful classrooms.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
And all the kids are thriving.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And how did we do all this?

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
On giant grass.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
It's bamboo.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
It comes out of the ground like a train.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
It grows as high as a coconut tree in two months

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
and three years later it can be harvested

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
to build buildings like this.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
It's as strong and dense as teak

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and it will hold up any roof.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
When the architects came, they brought us these things,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and you've probably seen things like this.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
The yellow box was called the administration complex.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
(Laughter)

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
We squashed it, we rethought it,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
but mainly we renamed it

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
"the heart of school,"

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and that changed everything forever.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
It's a double helix.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
It has administrators in it

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and many, many other things.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And the problem of building it --

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
when the Balinese workers

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
saw long reams of plans,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
they looked at them and said, "What's this?"

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
So we built big models.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
We had them engineered by the engineers.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
And Balinese carpenters like this

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
measured them with their bamboo rulers,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
selected the bamboo and built the buildings

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
using age-old techniques,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
mostly by hand.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
It was chaos.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And the Balinese carpenters want to be as modern as we do,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
so they use metal scaffolding

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
to build the bamboo building

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and when the scaffolding came down,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
we realized that we had a cathedral,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
a cathedral to green,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and a cathedral to green education.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
The heart of school has seven kilometers

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
of bamboo in it.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
From the time the foundations were finished,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in three months it had roofs and floors.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
It may not be the biggest bamboo building in the world,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
but many people believe

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
that it's the most beautiful.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Is this doable in your community?

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
We believe it is.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Green School is a model we built for the world.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
It's a model we built for Bali.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And you just have to follow these simple, simple rules:

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
be local,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
let the environment lead

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
and think about

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
how your grandchildren might build.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So, Mr. Gore, thank you.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
You ruined my life,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
but you gave me an incredible future.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And if you're interested in being involved

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
in finishing Green School

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
and building the next 50 around the world,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
please come and see us.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Thank you.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:24.958
(Applause)

title: Making law on the high seas
transcript: Today I'm going to take you on a voyage to some place so deep, so dark, so unexplored that we know less about it than we know about the dark side of the moon. It's a place of myth and legend. It's a place marked on ancient maps as "here be monsters." It is a place where each new voyage of exploration brings back new discoveries of creatures so wondrous and strange that our forefathers would have considered them monstrous indeed. Instead, they just make me green with envy that my colleague from IUCN was able to go on this journey to the south of Madagascar seamounts to actually take photographs and to see these wondrous creatures of the deep.We are talking about the high seas. The "high seas" is a legal term, but in fact, it covers 50 percent of the planet. With an average depth of the oceans of 4,000 meters, in fact, the high seas covers and provides nearly 90 percent of the habitat for life on this Earth. It is, in theory, the global commons, belonging to us all. But in reality, it is managed by and for those who have the resources to go out and exploit it. So today I'm going to take you on a voyage to cast light on some of the outdated myths and legends and assumptions that have kept us as the true stakeholders in the high seas in the dark. We're going to voyage to some of these special places that we've been discovering in the past few years to show why we really need to care. And then finally, we're going to try to develop and pioneer a new perspective on high seas governance that's rooted in ocean-basin-wide conservation, but framed in an arena of global norms of precaution and respect.So here is a picture of the high seas as seen from above — that area in the darker blue. To me, as an international lawyer, this scared me far more than any of the creatures or the monsters we may have seen, for it belies the notion that you can actually protect the ocean, the global ocean, that provides us all with carbon storage, with heat storage, with oxygen, if you can only protect 36 percent. This is indeed the true heart of the planet. Some of the problems that we have to confront are that the current international laws — for example, shipping — provide more protection to the areas closest to shore. For example, garbage discharge, something you would think just simply goes away, but the laws regulating ship discharge of garbage actually get weaker the further you are from shore. As a result, we have garbage patches the size of twice-Texas. It's unbelievable. We used to think the solution to pollution was dilution, but that has proved to be no longer the case.So what we have learned from social scientists and economists like Elinor Ostrom, who are studying the phenomenon of management of the commons on a local scale, is that there are certain prerequisites that you can put into place that enable you to manage and access open space for the good of one and all. And these include a sense of shared responsibility, common norms that bind people together as a community. Conditional access: You can invite people in, but they have to be able to play by the rules. And of course, if you want people to play by the rules, you still need an effective system of monitoring and enforcement, for as we've discovered, you can trust, but you also need to verify.What I'd also like to convey is that it is not all doom and gloom that we are seeing in the high seas. For a group of very dedicated individuals — scientists, conservationists, photographers and states — were able to actually change a tragic trajectory that was destroying fragile seascapes such as this coral garden that you see in front of you. That is, we're able to save it from a fate of deep-sea bottom trawling. And how did we do that? Well, as I said, we had a group of photographers that went out on board ships and actually photographed the activities in process. But we also spent many hours in the basements of the United Nations, trying to work with governments to make them understand what was going on so far away from land that few of us had ever even imagined that these creatures existed.So within three years, from 2003 to 2006, we were able to get norm in place that actually changed the paradigm of how fishers went about deep-sea bottom trawling. Instead of "go anywhere, do anything you want," we actually created a regime that required prior assessment of where you're going and a duty to prevent significant harm. In 2009, when the U.N. reviewed progress, they discovered that almost 100 million square-kilometers of seabed had been protected. This does not mean that it's the final solution, or that this even provides permanent protection. But what it does mean is that a group of individuals can form a community to actually shape the way high seas are governed, to create a new regime. So I'm looking optimistically at our opportunities for creating a true, blue perspective for this beautiful planet. Sylvia's wish provides us with that leverage, that access to the heart of human beings, you might say, who have rarely seen places beyond their own toes, but are now hopefully going to become interested in the full life-cycle of creatures like these sea turtles, who indeed spend most of their time in the high seas.Today, we're just going to voyage to a small sampling of some of these special areas, just to give you an idea of the flavor of the riches and wonders they do contain. The Sargasso Sea, for example, is not a sea bounded by coastlines, but it is bounded by oceanic currents that contain and envelope this wealth of sargassum that grows and aggregates there. It's also known as the spawning ground for eels from Northern European and Northern American rivers that are now so dwindling in numbers that they've actually stopped showing up in Stockholm, and five showed up in the U.K. just recently.But the Sargasso Sea, the same way it aggregates sargassum weed, actually is pulling in the plastic from throughout the region. This picture doesn't exactly show the plastics that I would like it to show, because I haven't been out there myself. But there has just been a study that was released in February that showed there are 200,000 pieces of plastic per square-kilometer now floating in the surface of the Sargasso Sea, and that is affecting the habitat for the many species in their juvenile stages who come to the Sargasso Sea for its protection and its food. The Sargasso Sea is also a wondrous place for the aggregation of these unique species that have developed to mimic the sargassum habitat. It also provides a special habitat for these flying fish to lay their eggs. But what I'd like to get from this picture is that we truly do have an opportunity to launch a global initiative for protection. Thus, the government of Bermuda has recognized the need and its responsibility as having some of the Sargasso Sea within its national jurisdiction — but the vast majority is beyond — to help spearhead a movement to achieve protection for this vital area.Spinning down to someplace a little bit cooler than here right now: the Ross Sea in the Southern Ocean. It's actually a bay. It's considered high seas, because the continent has been put off limits to territorial claims. So anything in the water is treated as if it's the high seas. But what makes the Ross Sea important is the vast sea of pack ice that in the spring and summer provides a wealth of phytoplankton and krill that supports what, till recently, has been a virtually intact near-shore ecosystem. But unfortunately, CCAMLR, the regional commission in charge of conserving and managing fish stocks and other living marine resources, is unfortunately starting to give in to fishing interests and has authorized the expansion of toothfish fisheries in the region. The captain of a New Zealand vessel who was just down there is reporting a significant decline in the number of the Ross Sea killer whales, who are directly dependent on the Antarctic toothfish as their main source of food. So what we need to do is to stand up boldly, singly and together, to push governments, to push regional fisheries management organizations, to declare our right to declare certain areas off-limits to high seas fishing, so that the freedom to fish no longer means the freedom to fish anywhere and anytime.Coming closer to here, the Costa Rica Dome is a recently discovered area — potentially year-round habitat for blue whales. There's enough food there to last them the summer and the winter long. But what's unusual about the Costa Rica Dome is, in fact, it's not a permanent place. It's an oceanographic phenomenon that shifts in time and space on a seasonal basis. So, in fact, it's not permanently in the high seas. It's not permanently in the exclusive economic zones of these five Central American countries, but it moves with the season. As such, it does create a challenge to protect, but we also have a challenge protecting the species that move along with it. We can use the same technologies that fishers use to identify where the species are, in order to close the area when it's most vulnerable, which may, in some cases, be year-round.Getting closer to shore, where we are, this was in fact taken in the Galapagos. Many species are headed through this region, which is why there's been so much attention put into conservation of the Eastern Tropical Pacific Seascape. This is the initiative that's been coordinated by Conservation International with a variety of partners and governments to actually try to bring integrated management regime throughout the area. That is, it provides a wonderful example of where you can go with a real regional initiative. It's protecting five World Heritage sites. Unfortunately, the World Heritage Convention does not recognize the need to protect areas beyond national jurisdiction, at present. So a place like the Costa Rica Dome could not technically qualify the time it's in the high seas. So what we've been suggesting is that we either need to amend the World Heritage Convention, so that it can adopt and urge universal protection of these World Heritage sites, or we need to change the name and call it Half-the-World Heritage Convention. But what we also know is that species like these sea turtles do not stay put in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Seascape. These happen to go down to a vast South Pacific Gyre, where they spend most of their time and often end up getting hooked like this, or as bycatch.So what I'd really like to suggest is that we need to scale-up. We need to work locally, but we also need to work ocean-basin-wide. We have the tools and technologies now to enable us to take a broader ocean-basin-wide initiative. We've heard about the Tagging of Pacific Predators project, one of the 17 Census of Marine Life projects. It's provided us data like this, of tiny, little sooty shearwaters that make the entire ocean basin their home. They fly 65,000 kilometers in less than a year. So we have the tools and treasures coming from the Census of Marine Life. And its culminating year that's going to be launched in October. So stay tuned for further information. What I find so exciting is that the Census of Marine Life has looked at more than the tagging of pacific predators; it's also looked in the really unexplored mid-water column, where creatures like this flying sea cucumber have been found. And fortunately, we've been able, as IUCN, to team up with the Census of Marine Life and many of the scientists working there to actually try to translate much of this information to policymakers. We have the support of governments now behind us. We've been revealing this information through technical workshops. And the exciting thing is that we do have sufficient information to move ahead to protect some of these significant hope spots, hotspots. At the same time we're saying, "Yes, we need more. We need to move forward."But many of you have said, if you get these marine protected areas, or a reasonable regime for high seas fisheries management in place, how are you going to enforce it? Which leads me to my second passion besides ocean science, which is outer space technology. I wanted to be an astronaut, so I've constantly followed what are the tools available to monitor Earth from outer space — and that we have incredible tools like we've been learning about, in terms of being able to follow tagged species throughout their life-cycles in the open ocean. We can also tag and track fishing vessels. Many already have transponders on board that allow us to find out where they are and even what they're doing. But not all the vessels have those to date. It does not take too much rocket science to actually try to create new laws to mandate, if you're going to have the privilege of accessing our high seas resources, we need to know — someone needs to know — where you are and what you're doing.So it brings me to my main take-home message, which is we can avert a tragedy of the commons. We can stop the collision course of 50 percent of the planet with the high seas. But we need to think broad-scale. We need to think globally. We need to change how we actually go about managing these resources. We need to get the new paradigm of precaution and respect. At the same time, we need to think locally, which is the joy and marvel of Sylvia's hope spot wish, is that we can shine a spotlight on many of these previously unknown areas, and to bring people to the table, if you will, to actually make them feel part of this community that truly has a stake in their future management. And third is that we need to look at ocean-basin-wide management. Our species are ocean-basin-wide. Many of the deep-sea communities have genetic distribution that goes ocean-basin-wide. We need to better understand, but we also need to start to manage and protect. And in order to do that, you also need ocean-basin management regimes. That is, we have regional management regimes within the exclusive economic zone, but we need to scale these up, we need to build their capacity, so they're like the Southern Ocean, where they do have the two-pronged fisheries and conservation organization.So with that, I would just like to sincerely thank and honor Sylvia Earle for her wish, for it is helping us to put a face on the high seas and the deep seas beyond national jurisdiction. It's helping to bring an incredible group of talented people together to really try to solve and penetrate these problems that have created our obstacles to management and rational use of this area that was once so far away and remote.So on this tour, I hope I provided you with a new perspective of the high seas: one, that it is our home too, and that we need to work together if we are to make this a sustainable ocean future for us all.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Today I'm going to take you on a voyage

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
to some place so deep,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
so dark, so unexplored

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
that we know less about it than we know about the dark side of the moon.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
It's a place of myth and legend.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
It's a place marked on ancient maps

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
as "here be monsters."

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
It is a place where each new voyage of exploration

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
brings back new discoveries of creatures so wondrous and strange

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
that our forefathers would have considered them monstrous indeed.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
Instead, they just make me green with envy

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
that my colleague from IUCN

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
was able to go on this journey to the south of Madagascar seamounts

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
to actually take photographs

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
and to see these wondrous creatures of the deep.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
We are talking about the high seas.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
The "high seas" is a legal term,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
but in fact, it covers 50 percent of the planet.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
With an average depth of the oceans

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
of 4,000 meters,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
in fact, the high seas covers and provides

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
nearly 90 percent of the habitat

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
for life on this Earth.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
It is, in theory, the global commons,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
belonging to us all.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
But in reality,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
it is managed by and for

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
those who have the resources

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
to go out and exploit it.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
So today I'm going to take you on a voyage

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
to cast light on some of the outdated myths

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
and legends and assumptions

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
that have kept us as the true stakeholders

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
in the high seas in the dark.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
We're going to voyage to some of these special places

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
that we've been discovering in the past few years

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
to show why we really need to care.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And then finally, we're going to try

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
to develop and pioneer a new perspective

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
on high seas governance

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
that's rooted in ocean-basin-wide conservation,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
but framed in an arena of global norms

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
of precaution and respect.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
So here is a picture of the high seas

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
as seen from above --

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
that area in the darker blue.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
To me, as an international lawyer,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
this scared me far more

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
than any of the creatures or the monsters we may have seen,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
for it belies the notion that you can actually protect the ocean,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
the global ocean,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
that provides us all with carbon storage,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
with heat storage, with oxygen,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
if you can only protect 36 percent.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
This is indeed the true heart of the planet.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
Some of the problems that we have to confront

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
are that the current international laws --

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
for example, shipping --

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
provide more protection

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
to the areas closest to shore.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
For example, garbage discharge,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
something you would think just simply goes away,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
but the laws regulating

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
ship discharge of garbage

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
actually get weaker the further you are from shore.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
As a result, we have garbage patches

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
the size of twice-Texas.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
It's unbelievable.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
We used to think the solution to pollution

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
was dilution,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
but that has proved to be no longer the case.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
So what we have learned from social scientists

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
and economists like Elinor Ostrom,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
who are studying the phenomenon

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
of management of the commons on a local scale,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
is that there are certain prerequisites

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
that you can put into place

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
that enable you to manage

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
and access open space

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
for the good of one and all.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And these include a sense of shared responsibility,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
common norms that bind people together as a community.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
Conditional access: You can invite people in,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
but they have to be able to play by the rules.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
And of course, if you want people to play by the rules,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
you still need an effective system

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
of monitoring and enforcement,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
for as we've discovered,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
you can trust, but you also need to verify.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
What I'd also like to convey

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
is that it is not all doom and gloom

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
that we are seeing in the high seas.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
For a group of very dedicated individuals --

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
scientists, conservationists,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
photographers and states --

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
were able to actually change a tragic trajectory

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
that was destroying fragile seascapes

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
such as this coral garden

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
that you see in front of you.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
That is, we're able to save it from a fate

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
of deep-sea bottom trawling.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And how did we do that?

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Well, as I said, we had a group of photographers that went out on board ships

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
and actually photographed the activities in process.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
But we also spent many hours

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
in the basements of the United Nations,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
trying to work with governments to make them understand

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
what was going on so far away from land

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
that few of us had ever even imagined

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
that these creatures existed.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
So within three years,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
from 2003 to 2006,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
we were able to get norm in place

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
that actually changed the paradigm

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
of how fishers went about

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
deep-sea bottom trawling.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
Instead of "go anywhere, do anything you want,"

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
we actually created a regime

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
that required prior assessment of where you're going

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and a duty to prevent significant harm.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
In 2009, when the U.N. reviewed progress,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
they discovered

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
that almost 100 million square-kilometers of seabed

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
had been protected.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
This does not mean that it's the final solution,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
or that this even provides permanent protection.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
But what it does mean

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
is that a group of individuals can form a community

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
to actually shape

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
the way high seas are governed,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
to create a new regime.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
So I'm looking optimistically at our opportunities

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
for creating a true, blue perspective

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
for this beautiful planet.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Sylvia's wish

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
provides us with that leverage, that access

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
to the heart of human beings,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
you might say,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
who have rarely seen places beyond their own toes,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
but are now hopefully going to become interested

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
in the full life-cycle of creatures like these sea turtles,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
who indeed spend most of their time in the high seas.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
Today, we're just going to voyage to a small sampling

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
of some of these special areas,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
just to give you an idea of the flavor

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
of the riches and wonders they do contain.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
The Sargasso Sea, for example,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
is not a sea bounded by coastlines,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
but it is bounded by oceanic currents

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
that contain and envelope

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
this wealth of sargassum

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
that grows and aggregates there.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
It's also known as the spawning ground for eels

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
from Northern European

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
and Northern American rivers

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
that are now so dwindling in numbers

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
that they've actually stopped showing up in Stockholm,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and five showed up in the U.K. just recently.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
But the Sargasso Sea,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
the same way it aggregates sargassum weed,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
actually is pulling in the plastic

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
from throughout the region.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
This picture doesn't exactly show

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
the plastics that I would like it to show, because I haven't been out there myself.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
But there has just been a study

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that was released in February

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
that showed there are 200,000

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
pieces of plastic per square-kilometer

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
now floating in the surface of the Sargasso Sea,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and that is affecting the habitat

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
for the many species in their juvenile stages

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
who come to the Sargasso Sea

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
for its protection and its food.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
The Sargasso Sea is also a wondrous place

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
for the aggregation of these unique species

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
that have developed to mimic the sargassum habitat.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
It also provides a special habitat

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
for these flying fish to lay their eggs.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
But what I'd like to get from this picture

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
is that we truly do have an opportunity

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
to launch a global initiative for protection.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
Thus, the government of Bermuda has recognized the need

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and its responsibility

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
as having some of the Sargasso Sea

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
within its national jurisdiction --

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
but the vast majority is beyond --

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
to help spearhead a movement

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
to achieve protection for this vital area.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Spinning down to someplace a little bit cooler than here right now:

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
the Ross Sea in the Southern Ocean.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
It's actually a bay.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
It's considered high seas, because the continent

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
has been put off limits

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
to territorial claims.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
So anything in the water is treated as if it's the high seas.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
But what makes the Ross Sea important

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
is the vast sea of pack ice

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
that in the spring and summer

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
provides a wealth of phytoplankton and krill

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
that supports what, till recently,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
has been a virtually intact

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
near-shore ecosystem.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
But unfortunately, CCAMLR,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
the regional commission

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
in charge of conserving and managing fish stocks

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and other living marine resources,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
is unfortunately starting to give in to fishing interests

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
and has authorized the expansion

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
of toothfish fisheries in the region.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
The captain of a New Zealand vessel

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
who was just down there

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
is reporting a significant decline

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
in the number of the Ross Sea killer whales,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
who are directly dependent on the Antarctic toothfish

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
as their main source of food.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
So what we need to do is to stand up boldly,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
singly and together,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
to push governments,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
to push regional fisheries management organizations,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
to declare our right

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
to declare certain areas off-limits to high seas fishing,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
so that the freedom to fish no longer means

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
the freedom to fish anywhere and anytime.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Coming closer to here, the Costa Rica Dome

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
is a recently discovered area --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
potentially year-round habitat for blue whales.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
There's enough food there to last them

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
the summer and the winter long.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
But what's unusual about the Costa Rica Dome

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
is, in fact, it's not a permanent place.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
It's an oceanographic phenomenon

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
that shifts in time and space on a seasonal basis.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
So, in fact, it's not permanently in the high seas.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
It's not permanently in the exclusive economic zones

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
of these five Central American countries,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
but it moves with the season.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
As such, it does create a challenge to protect,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
but we also have a challenge protecting the species that move along with it.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
We can use the same technologies that fishers use

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
to identify where the species are,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
in order to close the area

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
when it's most vulnerable,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
which may, in some cases, be year-round.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Getting closer to shore, where we are,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
this was in fact taken in the Galapagos.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Many species are headed through this region,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
which is why there's been so much attention

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
put into conservation

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
of the Eastern Tropical Pacific Seascape.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
This is the initiative that's been coordinated

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
by Conservation International

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
with a variety of partners and governments

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
to actually try to bring integrated management regime

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
throughout the area.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
That is, it provides a wonderful example of where you can go

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
with a real regional initiative.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
It's protecting five World Heritage sites.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Unfortunately, the World Heritage Convention

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
does not recognize the need to protect areas

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
beyond national jurisdiction, at present.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
So a place like the Costa Rica Dome

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
could not technically qualify

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
the time it's in the high seas.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
So what we've been suggesting

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
is that we either need to amend the World Heritage Convention,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
so that it can adopt

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and urge universal protection of these World Heritage sites,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
or we need to change the name

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and call it Half-the-World Heritage Convention.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
But what we also know is that species like these sea turtles

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
do not stay put in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Seascape.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
These happen to go down to a vast South Pacific Gyre,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
where they spend most of their time

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and often end up getting hooked like this,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
or as bycatch.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
So what I'd really like to suggest is that we need to scale-up.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
We need to work locally,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
but we also need to work ocean-basin-wide.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
We have the tools and technologies now

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
to enable us to take a broader

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
ocean-basin-wide initiative.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
We've heard about the Tagging of Pacific Predators project,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
one of the 17 Census of Marine Life projects.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
It's provided us data like this,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
of tiny, little sooty shearwaters

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
that make the entire ocean basin their home.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
They fly 65,000 kilometers

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
in less than a year.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
So we have the tools and treasures coming from the Census of Marine Life.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And its culminating year

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
that's going to be launched in October.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
So stay tuned for further information.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
What I find so exciting

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
is that the Census of Marine Life

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
has looked at more than the tagging of pacific predators;

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
it's also looked in the really unexplored mid-water column,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
where creatures like this flying sea cucumber

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
have been found.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And fortunately, we've been able, as IUCN,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
to team up with the Census of Marine Life

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and many of the scientists working there

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
to actually try to translate

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
much of this information to policymakers.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
We have the support of governments now behind us.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
We've been revealing this information through technical workshops.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And the exciting thing is that we do have sufficient information

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
to move ahead to protect some of these

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
significant hope spots, hotspots.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
At the same time we're saying,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
"Yes, we need more. We need to move forward."

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
But many of you have said,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
if you get these marine protected areas,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
or a reasonable regime for high seas fisheries management in place,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
how are you going to enforce it?

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Which leads me to my second passion besides ocean science,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
which is outer space technology.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
I wanted to be an astronaut,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
so I've constantly followed

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
what are the tools available to monitor Earth

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
from outer space --

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and that we have incredible tools like we've been learning about,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
in terms of being able to follow tagged species

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
throughout their life-cycles

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
in the open ocean.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
We can also tag and track fishing vessels.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Many already have transponders on board

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
that allow us to find out where they are and even what they're doing.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
But not all the vessels have those to date.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
It does not take too much rocket science

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
to actually try to create new laws to mandate,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
if you're going to have the privilege

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
of accessing our high seas resources,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
we need to know -- someone needs to know --

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
where you are and what you're doing.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
So it brings me to my main take-home message,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
which is we can avert a tragedy of the commons.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
We can stop the collision course

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
of 50 percent of the planet

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
with the high seas.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
But we need to think broad-scale. We need to think globally.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
We need to change how we actually go about

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
managing these resources.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
We need to get the new paradigm

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
of precaution and respect.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
At the same time, we need to think locally,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
which is the joy and marvel of Sylvia's hope spot wish,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
is that we can shine a spotlight

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
on many of these previously unknown areas,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
and to bring people to the table, if you will,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
to actually make them feel part of this community

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
that truly has a stake

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
in their future management.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And third is that we need to look at ocean-basin-wide management.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
Our species are ocean-basin-wide.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
Many of the deep-sea communities

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
have genetic distribution

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
that goes ocean-basin-wide.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
We need to better understand,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
but we also need to start to manage and protect.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And in order to do that,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
you also need ocean-basin management regimes.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
That is, we have regional management regimes

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
within the exclusive economic zone,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
but we need to scale these up, we need to build their capacity,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
so they're like the Southern Ocean,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
where they do have the two-pronged fisheries

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
and conservation organization.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
So with that, I would just like to sincerely thank and honor

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
Sylvia Earle for her wish,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
for it is helping us to put a face on the high seas

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and the deep seas beyond national jurisdiction.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
It's helping to bring an incredible group

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
of talented people together

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
to really try to solve and penetrate

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
these problems that have created our obstacles

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
to management and rational use

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
of this area that was once so far away and remote.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
So on this tour, I hope I provided you

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
with a new perspective of the high seas:

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
one, that it is our home too,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and that we need to work together

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
if we are to make this a sustainable ocean future for us all.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
Thank you.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
(Applause)

title: Protecting the brain against concussion
transcript: So, a funny thing happened on my way to becoming a brilliant, world-class neuropsychologist: I had a baby. And that's not to say I ever went on to become a brilliant, world-class neuropsychologist. Sorry, TED. But I did go on to be a reasonably astute, arguably world-class worrier. One of my girlfriends in graduate school, Marie, said, "Kim, I figured it out. It's not that you're more neurotic than everyone else; it's just that you're more honest about how neurotic you are."So in the spirit of full disclosure, I brought some pictures to share. Awwww.(Laughter)I'll just say: July.(Laughter)Zip!(Laughter)For safety.(Laughter)Water wings — an inch of water. And then, finally, all suited up for the 90-minute drive to Copper Mountain. So you can get kind of a feel for this. So my baby, Vander, is eight years old now. And, despite being cursed with my athletic inability, he plays soccer. He's interested in playing football. He wants to learn how to ride a unicycle.So why would I worry? Because this is what I do. This is what I teach. It's what I study. It's what I treat. And I know that kids get concussed every year. In fact, more than four million people sustain a concussion every year, and these data are just among kids under 14 who were seen in emergency rooms. And so when kids sustain a concussion, we talk about them getting dinged or getting their bell rung, but what is it that we're really talking about? Let's take a look.[Concussive Force]"Starsky and Hutch"? Arguably, yes. So, a car accident. Forty miles an hour into a fixed barrier: 35 Gs. A heavyweight boxer punches you straight in the face: 58 Gs.(Music)In case you missed it, we'll look again. So look to the right-hand side of the screen.(Music)What would you say? How many Gs? Close. Seventy-two? Would it be crazy to know: 103 Gs? The average concussive impact is 95 Gs. Now, when the kid on the right doesn't get up, we know they've had a concussion.But how about the kid on the left, or the athlete that leaves the field of play? How do we know if he or she has sustained a concussion? How do we know that legislation that would require they be pulled from play, cleared for return to play, applies to them? The definition of concussion doesn't actually require a loss of consciousness. It requires only a change in consciousness, and that can be any one or a number of symptoms, including feeling foggy, feeling dizzy, hearing a ringing in your ear, being more impulsive or hostile than usual.So given all of that and given how darn neurotic I am, how do I get any sleep at all? Because I know our brains are resilient. They're designed to recover from an injury. If — God forbid — any of us left here tonight and sustained a concussion, most of us would go on to fully recover inside of a couple hours to a couple of weeks. But kids are more vulnerable to brain injury. In fact, high-school athletes are three times more likely to sustain catastrophic injuries relative even to their college-age peers, and it takes them longer to return to a symptom-free baseline. After that first injury, their risk for second injury is exponentially greater. From there, their risk for a third injury, greater still, and so on.And here's the really alarming part: We don't fully understand the long-term impact of multiple injuries. You guys may be familiar with this research that's coming out of the NFL. In a nutshell, this research suggests that, among retired NFL players with three or more career concussions, the incidence of early-onset dementing disease is much greater than it is for the general population. So you've all seen that — New York Times, you've seen it. What you may not be familiar with is that this research was spearheaded by NFL wives who said, "Isn't it weird that my 46-year-old husband is forever losing his keys?" "Isn't it weird that my 47-year-old husband is forever losing the car?" "Isn't it weird that my 48-year-old husband is forever losing his way home in the car, from the driveway?" I may have forgotten to mention that my son is an only child. So it's going to be really important that he be able to drive me around someday.(Laughter)So, how do we guarantee the safety of our kids? How can we 100 percent guarantee the safety of our kids? Let me tell you what I've come up with.(Laughter)If only. My little boy's right there, and he's like, "She's not kidding. She's totally not kidding." So in all seriousness: Should my kid play football? Should your kid play football? I don't know. But I do know there are three things you can do. The first: study up. You have to be familiar with the issues we're talking about today. There are some great resources out there.The CDC has a program, HEADS UP. It's at CDC.gov. HEADS UP is specific to concussion in kids. The second is a resource I'm personally really proud of. We've just rolled this out in the last couple months — CO Kids With Brain Injury. This is a great resource for student athletes, teachers, parents, professionals, athletic and coaching staff. It's a great place to start if you have questions.The second thing is: speak up. Just two weeks ago, a bill introduced by Senator Kefalas that would have required athletes, kids under 18, to wear a helmet when they're riding their bike, died in committee. It died, in large part, because it lacked constituent buy-in; it lacked stakeholder traction. Now, I'm not here to tell you what kind of legislation you should or shouldn't support, but I am going to tell you that, if it matters to you, your legislators need to know that.Speak up also with coaching staff. Ask about what kind of protective equipment is available. What's the budget for protective equipment? How old it is? Maybe offer to spearhead a fundraiser to buy new gear.Which brings us to: suit up. Wear a helmet. The only way to prevent a bad outcome is to prevent that first injury from happening. Recently, one of my graduate students, Tom, said, "Kim, I've decided to wear a bike helmet on the way to class." And Tom knows that that little bit of foam in a bike helmet can reduce the g-force of impact by half. Now, I thought it was because I have this totally compelling helmet crusade, this epiphany of Tom's. As it turns out, it occurred to Tom that a $20 helmet is a good way to protect a $100,000 graduate education.(Laughter)So ... Should Vander play football? I can't say no, but I can guarantee that every time he leaves the house, that kid's wearing a helmet — like, to the car, or at school. So whether athlete, scholar, overprotected kid, neurotic mom, or otherwise, here's my baby, Vander, reminding you to mind your matter.Thank you.(Applause)
