00:04:18.874 --> 00:04:21.375
relative even to their college-age peers,

00:04:21.399 --> 00:04:25.064
and it takes them longer
to return to a symptom-free baseline.

00:04:26.706 --> 00:04:28.936
After that first injury,

00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:32.766
their risk for second injury
is exponentially greater.

00:04:32.790 --> 00:04:37.703
From there, their risk for a third injury,
greater still, and so on.

00:04:38.710 --> 00:04:41.548
And here's the really alarming part:

00:04:42.101 --> 00:04:46.865
We don't fully understand
the long-term impact of multiple injuries.

00:04:47.857 --> 00:04:49.981
You guys may be familiar
with this research

00:04:50.005 --> 00:04:51.583
that's coming out of the NFL.

00:04:52.448 --> 00:04:55.165
In a nutshell,
this research suggests that,

00:04:55.189 --> 00:05:00.432
among retired NFL players
with three or more career concussions,

00:05:00.456 --> 00:05:03.432
the incidence of early-onset
dementing disease

00:05:03.456 --> 00:05:06.221
is much greater than it
is for the general population.

00:05:06.784 --> 00:05:09.634
So you've all seen that --
New York Times, you've seen it.

00:05:09.658 --> 00:05:11.260
What you may not be familiar with

00:05:11.284 --> 00:05:16.403
is that this research was spearheaded
by NFL wives who said,

00:05:16.427 --> 00:05:19.404
"Isn't it weird
that my 46-year-old husband

00:05:19.428 --> 00:05:21.091
is forever losing his keys?"

00:05:21.491 --> 00:05:24.262
"Isn't it weird that
my 47-year-old husband

00:05:24.286 --> 00:05:26.166
is forever losing the car?"

00:05:26.793 --> 00:05:29.658
"Isn't it weird that
my 48-year-old husband

00:05:29.682 --> 00:05:31.703
is forever losing his way home

00:05:31.727 --> 00:05:34.678
in the car, from the driveway?"

00:05:34.996 --> 00:05:39.589
I may have forgotten to mention
that my son is an only child.

00:05:40.818 --> 00:05:43.598
So it's going to be really important

00:05:43.622 --> 00:05:47.622
that he be able to drive
me around someday.

00:05:47.974 --> 00:05:49.124
(Laughter)

00:05:49.148 --> 00:05:53.980
So, how do we guarantee
the safety of our kids?

00:05:54.507 --> 00:05:59.340
How can we 100 percent
guarantee the safety of our kids?

00:05:59.364 --> 00:06:01.270
Let me tell you what I've come up with.

00:06:02.841 --> 00:06:07.634
(Laughter)

00:06:07.658 --> 00:06:08.966
If only.

00:06:08.990 --> 00:06:11.979
My little boy's right there,
and he's like, "She's not kidding.

00:06:12.003 --> 00:06:13.406
She's totally not kidding."

00:06:14.172 --> 00:06:16.740
So in all seriousness:

00:06:16.764 --> 00:06:18.411
Should my kid play football?

00:06:18.435 --> 00:06:20.222
Should your kid play football?

00:06:20.246 --> 00:06:21.412
I don't know.

00:06:21.436 --> 00:06:24.943
But I do know there are
three things you can do.

00:06:24.967 --> 00:06:27.809
The first: study up.

00:06:27.833 --> 00:06:31.562
You have to be familiar with the issues
we're talking about today.

00:06:31.586 --> 00:06:34.152
There are some great resources out there.

00:06:34.176 --> 00:06:36.470
The CDC has a program, HEADS UP.

00:06:36.494 --> 00:06:38.128
It's at CDC.gov.

00:06:38.152 --> 00:06:41.540
HEADS UP is specific
to concussion in kids.

00:06:41.564 --> 00:06:44.814
The second is a resource
I'm personally really proud of.

00:06:44.838 --> 00:06:47.480
We've just rolled this out
in the last couple months --

00:06:47.504 --> 00:06:48.876
CO Kids With Brain Injury.

00:06:49.197 --> 00:06:51.849
This is a great resource
for student athletes,

00:06:51.873 --> 00:06:56.262
teachers, parents, professionals,
athletic and coaching staff.

00:06:56.286 --> 00:07:00.039
It's a great place to start
if you have questions.

00:07:00.841 --> 00:07:02.982
The second thing is: speak up.

00:07:04.163 --> 00:07:05.372
Just two weeks ago,

00:07:05.396 --> 00:07:07.373
a bill introduced by Senator Kefalas

00:07:07.397 --> 00:07:11.307
that would have required
athletes, kids under 18,

00:07:11.331 --> 00:07:13.645
to wear a helmet
when they're riding their bike,

00:07:13.669 --> 00:07:14.933
died in committee.

00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:18.137
It died, in large part,

00:07:18.161 --> 00:07:21.091
because it lacked constituent buy-in;

00:07:21.115 --> 00:07:23.228
it lacked stakeholder traction.

00:07:23.618 --> 00:07:25.034
Now, I'm not here to tell you

00:07:25.058 --> 00:07:27.959
what kind of legislation
you should or shouldn't support,

00:07:27.983 --> 00:07:31.057
but I am going to tell you
that, if it matters to you,

00:07:31.081 --> 00:07:33.995
your legislators need to know that.

00:07:34.602 --> 00:07:36.425
Speak up also with coaching staff.

00:07:36.449 --> 00:07:39.426
Ask about what kind
of protective equipment is available.

00:07:39.450 --> 00:07:41.499
What's the budget
for protective equipment?

00:07:41.523 --> 00:07:43.073
How old it is?

00:07:43.097 --> 00:07:46.803
Maybe offer to spearhead
a fundraiser to buy new gear.

00:07:46.827 --> 00:07:49.824
Which brings us to: suit up.

00:07:49.848 --> 00:07:51.315
Wear a helmet.

00:07:52.380 --> 00:07:55.634
The only way to prevent a bad outcome

00:07:55.658 --> 00:07:58.658
is to prevent that first injury
from happening.

00:07:59.658 --> 00:08:04.217
Recently, one of my graduate
students, Tom, said,

00:08:04.241 --> 00:08:07.810
"Kim, I've decided to wear a bike helmet
on the way to class."

00:08:08.642 --> 00:08:12.538
And Tom knows that that little bit
of foam in a bike helmet

00:08:12.562 --> 00:08:15.854
can reduce the g-force of impact by half.

00:08:16.616 --> 00:08:21.577
Now, I thought it was because I have
this totally compelling helmet crusade,

00:08:21.601 --> 00:08:23.309
this epiphany of Tom's.

00:08:23.744 --> 00:08:27.411
As it turns out, it occurred
to Tom that a $20 helmet

00:08:27.435 --> 00:08:31.634
is a good way to protect
a $100,000 graduate education.

00:08:31.658 --> 00:08:33.682
(Laughter)

00:08:33.706 --> 00:08:35.229
So ...

00:08:37.037 --> 00:08:38.704
Should Vander play football?

00:08:40.069 --> 00:08:41.372
I can't say no,

00:08:41.396 --> 00:08:45.634
but I can guarantee that every time
he leaves the house,

00:08:45.658 --> 00:08:47.267
that kid's wearing a helmet --

00:08:48.380 --> 00:08:50.357
like, to the car,

00:08:50.381 --> 00:08:52.095
or at school.

00:08:53.046 --> 00:08:55.727
So whether athlete, scholar,

00:08:55.751 --> 00:08:58.426
overprotected kid, neurotic mom,

00:08:58.450 --> 00:09:00.236
or otherwise,

00:09:00.260 --> 00:09:02.148
here's my baby, Vander,

00:09:02.172 --> 00:09:03.553
reminding you

00:09:03.577 --> 00:09:06.092
to mind your matter.

00:09:06.658 --> 00:09:07.826
Thank you.

00:09:07.850 --> 00:09:13.108
(Applause)

title: Women, wartime and the dream of peace
transcript: I woke up in the middle of the night with the sound of heavy explosion. It was deep at night. I do not remember what time it was. I just remember the sound was so heavy and so very shocking. Everything in my room was shaking — my heart, my windows, my bed, everything. I looked out the windows and I saw a full half-circle of explosion. I thought it was just like the movies, but the movies had not conveyed them in the powerful image that I was seeing full of bright red and orange and gray, and a full circle of explosion. And I kept on staring at it until it disappeared. I went back to my bed, and I prayed, and I secretly thanked God that that missile did not land on my family's home, that it did not kill my family that night. Thirty years have passed, and I still feel guilty about that prayer, for the next day, I learned that that missile landed on my brother's friend's home and killed him and his father, but did not kill his mother or his sister. His mother showed up the next week at my brother's classroom and begged seven-year-old kids to share with her any picture they may have of her son, for she had lost everything.This is not a story of a nameless survivor of war, and nameless refugees, whose stereotypical images we see in our newspapers and our TV with tattered clothes, dirty face, scared eyes. This is not a story of a nameless someone who lived in some war, who we do not know their hopes, their dreams, their accomplishments, their families, their beliefs, their values. This is my story. I was that girl. I am another image and vision of another survivor of war. I am that refugee, and I am that girl. You see, I grew up in war-torn Iraq, and I believe that there are two sides of wars and we've only seen one side of it. We only talk about one side of it. But there's another side that I have witnessed as someone who lived in it and someone who ended up working in it.I grew up with the colors of war — the red colors of fire and blood, the brown tones of earth as it explodes in our faces and the piercing silver of an exploded missile, so bright that nothing can protect your eyes from it. I grew up with the sounds of war — the staccato sounds of gunfire, the wrenching booms of explosions, ominous drones of jets flying overhead and the wailing warning sounds of sirens. These are the sounds you would expect, but they are also the sounds of dissonant concerts of a flock of birds screeching in the night, the high-pitched honest cries of children and the thunderous, unbearable silence. "War," a friend of mine said, "is not about sound at all. It is actually about silence, the silence of humanity."I have since left Iraq and founded a group called Women for Women International that ends up working with women survivors of wars. In my travels and in my work, from Congo to Afghanistan, from Sudan to Rwanda, I have learned not only that the colors and the sounds of war are the same, but the fears of war are the same. You know, there is a fear of dying, and do not believe any movie character where the hero is not afraid. It is very scary to go through that feeling of "I am about to die" or "I could die in this explosion." But there's also the fear of losing loved ones, and I think that's even worse. It's too painful. You don't want to think about it. But I think the worst kind of fear is the fear — as Samia, a Bosnian woman, once told me, who survived the four-years besiege of Sarajevo; she said, "The fear of losing the 'I' in me, the fear of losing the 'I' in me." That's what my mother in Iraq used to tell me. It's like dying from inside-out. A Palestinian woman once told me, "It is not about the fear of one death," she said, "sometimes I feel I die 10 times in one day," as she was describing the marches of soldiers and the sounds of their bullets. She said, "But it's not fair, because there is only one life, and there should only be one death."We have been only seeing one side of war. We have only been discussing and consumed with high-level preoccupations over troop levels, drawdown timelines, surges and sting operations, when we should be examining the details of where the social fabric has been most torn, where the community has improvised and survived and shown acts of resilience and amazing courage just to keep life going. We have been so consumed with seemingly objective discussions of politics, tactics, weapons, dollars and casualties. This is the language of sterility.How casually we treat casualties in the context of this topic. This is where we conceive of rape and casualties as inevitabilities. Eighty percent of refugees around the world are women and children. Oh. Ninety percent of modern war casualties are civilians. Seventy-five percent of them are women and children. How interesting. Oh, half a million women in Rwanda get raped in 100 days. Or, as we speak now, hundreds of thousands of Congolese women are getting raped and mutilated. How interesting. These just become numbers that we refer to. The front of wars is increasingly non-human eyes peering down on our perceived enemies from space, guiding missiles toward unseen targets, while the human conduct of the orchestra of media relations in the event that this particular drone attack hits a villager instead of an extremist. It is a chess game. You learn to play an international relations school on your way out and up to national and international leadership. Checkmate.We are missing a completely other side of wars. We are missing my mother's story, who made sure with every siren, with every raid, with every cut off-of electricity, she played puppet shows for my brothers and I, so we would not be scared of the sounds of explosions. We are missing the story of Fareeda, a music teacher, a piano teacher, in Sarajevo, who made sure that she kept the music school open every single day in the four years of besiege in Sarajevo and walked to that school, despite the snipers shooting at that school and at her, and kept the piano, the violin, the cello playing the whole duration of the war, with students wearing their gloves and hats and coats. That was her fight. That was her resistance. We are missing the story of Nehia, a Palestinian woman in Gaza who, the minute there was a cease-fire in the last year's war, she left out of home, collected all the flour and baked as much bread for every neighbor to have, in case there is no cease-fire the day after. We are missing the stories of Violet, who, despite surviving genocide in the church massacre, she kept on going on, burying bodies, cleaning homes, cleaning the streets. We are missing stories of women who are literally keeping life going in the midst of wars. Do you know — do you know that people fall in love in war and go to school and go to factories and hospitals and get divorced and go dancing and go playing and live life going? And the ones who are keeping that life are women.There are two sides of war. There is a side that fights, and there is a side that keeps the schools and the factories and the hospitals open. There is a side that is focused on winning battles, and there is a side that is focused on winning life. There is a side that leads the front-line discussion, and there is a side that leads the back-line discussion. There is a side that thinks that peace is the end of fighting, and there is a side that thinks that peace is the arrival of schools and jobs. There is a side that is led by men, and there is a side that is led by women. And in order for us to understand how do we build lasting peace, we must understand war and peace from both sides. We must have a full picture of what that means.In order for us to understand what actually peace means, we need to understand, as one Sudanese woman once told me, "Peace is the fact that my toenails are growing back again." She grew up in Sudan, in Southern Sudan, for 20 years of war, where it killed one million people and displaced five million refugees. Many women were taken as slaves by rebels and soldiers, as sexual slaves who were forced also to carry the ammunition and the water and the food for the soldiers. So that woman walked for 20 years, so she would not be kidnapped again. And only when there was some sort of peace, her toenails grew back again. We need to understand peace from a toenail's perspective.We need to understand that we cannot actually have negotiations of ending of wars or peace without fully including women at the negotiating table. I find it amazing that the only group of people who are not fighting and not killing and not pillaging and not burning and not raping, and the group of people who are mostly — though not exclusively — who are keeping life going in the midst of war, are not included in the negotiating table. And I do argue that women lead the back-line discussion, but there are also men who are excluded from that discussion. The doctors who are not fighting, the artists, the students, the men who refuse to pick up the guns, they are, too, excluded from the negotiating tables. There is no way we can talk about a lasting peace, building of democracy, sustainable economies, any kind of stabilities, if we do not fully include women at the negotiating table. Not one, but 50 percent.There is no way we can talk about the building of stability if we don't start investing in women and girls. Did you know that one year of the world's military spending equals 700 years of the U.N. budget and equals 2,928 years of the U.N. budget allocated for women? If we just reverse that distribution of funds, perhaps we could have a better lasting peace in this world. And last, but not least, we need to invest in peace and women, not only because it is the right thing to do, not only because it is the right thing to do, for all of us to build sustainable and lasting peace today, but it is for the future.A Congolese woman, who was telling me about how her children saw their father killed in front of them and saw her raped in front of them and mutilated in front of them, and her children saw their nine-year-old sibling killed in front of them, how they're doing okay right now. She got into Women for Women International's program. She got a support network. She learned about her rights. We taught her vocational and business skills. We helped her get a job. She was earning 450 dollars. She was doing okay. She was sending them to school. Have a new home. She said, "But what I worry about the most is not any of that. I worry that my children have hate in their hearts, and when they want to grow up, they want to fight again the killers of their father and their brother." We need to invest in women, because that's our only chance to ensure that there is no more war in the future. That mother has a better chance to heal her children than any peace agreement can do.Are there good news? Of course, there are good news. There are lots of good news. To start with, these women that I told you about are dancing and singing every single day, and if they can, who are we not to dance? That girl that I told you about ended up starting Women for Women International Group that impacted one million people, sent 80 million dollars, and I started this from zero, nothing, nada, [unclear].(Laughter)They are women who are standing on their feet in spite of their circumstances, not because of it. Think of how the world can be a much better place if, for a change, we have a better equality, we have equality, we have a representation and we understand war, both from the front-line and the back-line discussion.Rumi, a 13th-century Sufi poet, says, "Out beyond the worlds of right-doings and wrong-doings, there is a field. I will meet you there. When the soul lies down in that grass, the world is too full to talk about. Ideas, language, even the phrase 'each other' no longer makes any sense." I humbly add — humbly add — that out beyond the worlds of war and peace, there is a field, and there are many women and men [who] are meeting there. Let us make this field a much bigger place. Let us all meet in that field.Thank you.(Applause)

It is actually about silence,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
the silence of humanity."

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
I have since left Iraq

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
and founded a group called Women for Women International

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
that ends up working

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
with women survivors of wars.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
In my travels and in my work,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
from Congo to Afghanistan,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
from Sudan to Rwanda,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
I have learned not only

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
that the colors and the sounds of war are the same,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
but the fears of war are the same.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
You know, there is a fear of dying,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and do not believe any movie character

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
where the hero is not afraid.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
It is very scary

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
to go through that feeling

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
of "I am about to die"

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
or "I could die in this explosion."

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
But there's also the fear

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
of losing loved ones,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
and I think that's even worse.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
It's too painful. You don't want to think about it.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
But I think the worst kind of fear is the fear --

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
as Samia, a Bosnian woman, once told me,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
who survived the four-years besiege of Sarajevo;

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
she said, "The fear

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
of losing

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
the 'I' in me,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
the fear of losing

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
the 'I' in me."

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
That's what my mother in Iraq

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
used to tell me.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
It's like dying from inside-out.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
A Palestinian woman once told me,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
"It is not about the fear of one death,"

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
she said, "sometimes I feel

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
I die 10 times in one day,"

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
as she was describing the marches of soldiers

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and the sounds of their bullets.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
She said, "But it's not fair,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
because there is only one life,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
and there should only be one death."

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
We have been only seeing

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
one side of war.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
We have only been discussing and consumed

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
with high-level preoccupations

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
over troop levels, drawdown timelines,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
surges and sting operations,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
when we should be examining the details

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
of where the social fabric

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
has been most torn,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
where the community has improvised

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
and survived

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and shown acts of resilience

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
and amazing courage

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
just to keep life going.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
We have been so consumed

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
with seemingly objective discussions

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
of politics, tactics,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
weapons, dollars

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and casualties.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
This is the language

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
of sterility.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
How casually

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
we treat casualties

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
in the context of this topic.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
This is where we conceive of rape and casualties

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
as inevitabilities.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Eighty percent of refugees around the world

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
are women and children. Oh.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Ninety percent of modern war casualties

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
are civilians.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Seventy-five percent of them are women and children.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
How interesting.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
Oh, half a million women in Rwanda

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
get raped in 100 days.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Or, as we speak now,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
hundreds of thousands of Congolese women

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
are getting raped and mutilated.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
How interesting.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
These just become numbers that we refer to.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
The front of wars

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
is increasingly non-human eyes

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
peering down on our perceived enemies

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
from space,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
guiding missiles toward unseen targets,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
while the human conduct

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
of the orchestra of media relations

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
in the event that this particular drone attack

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
hits a villager

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
instead of an extremist.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
It is a chess game.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
You learn to play an international relations school

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
on your way out and up

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
to national and international leadership.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
Checkmate.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
We are missing

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
a completely other side of wars.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
We are missing my mother's story,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
who made sure with every siren, with every raid,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
with every cut off-of electricity,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
she played puppet shows for my brothers and I,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
so we would not be scared

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
of the sounds of explosions.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
We are missing the story of Fareeda,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
a music teacher,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
a piano teacher, in Sarajevo,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
who made sure

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
that she kept the music school open

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
every single day

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
in the four years of besiege in Sarajevo

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
and walked to that school,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
despite the snipers shooting

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
at that school and at her,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
and kept the piano, the violin, the cello

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
playing the whole duration of the war,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
with students wearing their gloves and hats and coats.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
That was her fight.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
That was her resistance.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
We are missing the story of Nehia,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
a Palestinian woman in Gaza

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
who, the minute there was a cease-fire in the last year's war,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
she left out of home,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
collected all the flour

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
and baked as much bread for every neighbor to have,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
in case there is no cease-fire the day after.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
We are missing

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
the stories of Violet,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
who, despite surviving genocide in the church massacre,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
she kept on going on,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
burying bodies, cleaning homes, cleaning the streets.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
We are missing stories of women

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
who are literally keeping life going

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
in the midst of wars.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Do you know --

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
do you know that people fall in love in war

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and go to school

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and go to factories and hospitals

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and get divorced and go dancing and go playing

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and live life going?

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
And the ones who are keeping that life

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
are women.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
There are two sides of war.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
There is a side that fights,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and there is a side that keeps the schools

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and the factories and the hospitals open.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
There is a side that is focused on winning battles,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and there is a side that is focused

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
on winning life.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
There is a side that leads the front-line discussion,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and there is a side

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
that leads the back-line discussion.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
There is a side that thinks

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
that peace is the end of fighting,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and there is a side that thinks

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
that peace is the arrival

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
of schools and jobs.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
There is a side

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
that is led by men,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and there is a side

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
that is led by women.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And in order for us to understand

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
how do we build lasting peace,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
we must understand war and peace

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
from both sides.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
We must have a full picture

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
of what that means.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
In order for us to understand

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
what actually peace means,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
we need to understand,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
as one Sudanese woman once told me,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
"Peace is the fact that my toenails

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
are growing back again."

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
She grew up in Sudan, in Southern Sudan,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
for 20 years of war,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
where it killed one million people

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and displaced five million refugees.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Many women were taken as slaves

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
by rebels and soldiers,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
as sexual slaves who were forced also

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
to carry the ammunition and the water

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and the food for the soldiers.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
So that woman walked for 20 years,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
so she would not be kidnapped again.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And only when there was some sort of peace,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
her toenails grew back again.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
We need to understand peace

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
from a toenail's perspective.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
We need to understand

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
that we cannot actually have negotiations

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
of ending of wars or peace

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
without fully including women

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
at the negotiating table.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
I find it amazing

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
that the only group of people

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
who are not fighting and not killing

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and not pillaging and not burning and not raping,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and the group of people who are mostly --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
though not exclusively --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
who are keeping life going in the midst of war,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
are not included in the negotiating table.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And I do argue that women lead the back-line discussion,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
but there are also men

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
who are excluded from that discussion.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
The doctors who are not fighting,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
the artists, the students, the men who refuse to pick up the guns,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
they are, too, excluded

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
from the negotiating tables.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
There is no way we can talk about a lasting peace,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
building of democracy, sustainable economies,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
any kind of stabilities,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
if we do not fully include women

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
at the negotiating table.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Not one, but 50 percent.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
There is no way we can talk about the building of stability

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
if we don't start investing

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
in women and girls.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Did you know

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
that one year

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
of the world's military spending

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
equals 700 years

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
of the U.N. budget

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and equals 2,928 years

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
of the U.N. budget allocated for women?

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
If we just reverse

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
that distribution of funds,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
perhaps we could have

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
a better lasting peace in this world.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And last, but not least,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
we need to invest in peace and women,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
not only because it is the right thing to do,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
not only because it is the right thing to do,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
for all of us to build sustainable and lasting peace today,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
but it is for the future.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
A Congolese woman,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
who was telling me about

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
how her children saw their father killed in front of them

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
and saw her raped in front of them

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
and mutilated in front of them,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and her children saw their nine-year-old sibling

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
killed in front of them,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
how they're doing okay right now.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
She got into Women for Women International's program.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
She got a support network.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
She learned about her rights.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
We taught her vocational and business skills. We helped her get a job.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
She was earning 450 dollars. She was doing okay.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
She was sending them to school. Have a new home.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
She said, "But what I worry about the most

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
is not any of that.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
I worry that my children

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
have hate in their hearts,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
and when they want to grow up, they want to fight again

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
the killers of their father and their brother."

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
We need to invest in women,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
because that's our only chance

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
to ensure that there is no more war

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
in the future.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
That mother has a better chance to heal her children

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
than any peace agreement can do.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Are there good news? Of course, there are good news. There are lots of good news.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
To start with, these women that I told you about

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
are dancing and singing every single day,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
and if they can,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
who are we not to dance?

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
That girl that I told you about

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
ended up starting Women for Women International Group

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
that impacted one million people, sent 80 million dollars,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
and I started this from zero,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
nothing, nada, [unclear].

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
(Laughter)

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
They are women who are standing on their feet

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
in spite of their circumstances,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
not because of it.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
Think of how the world can be a much better place

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
if, for a change,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
we have a better equality,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
we have equality,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
we have a representation

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and we understand war,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
both from the front-line

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
and the back-line discussion.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Rumi, a 13th-century Sufi poet,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
says, "Out beyond the worlds

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
of right-doings and wrong-doings,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
there is a field.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
I will meet you there.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
When the soul lies down in that grass,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
the world is too full

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
to talk about.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Ideas, language,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
even the phrase 'each other'

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
no longer makes any sense."

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
I humbly add -- humbly add --

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
that out beyond

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
the worlds of war and peace,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
there is a field,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
and there are many women and men

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
[who] are meeting there.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
Let us make this field a much bigger place.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Let us all meet in that field.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
Thank you.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:35.958
(Applause)

title: Why work doesn't happen at work
transcript: So I'm going to talk about work; specifically, why people can't seem to get work done at work, which is a problem we all kind of have. But let's sort of start at the beginning.So, we have companies and non-profits and charities and all these groups that have employees or volunteers of some sort. And they expect these people who work for them to do great work — I would hope, at least. At least good work, hopefully, at least it's good work — hopefully great work. And so what they typically do is they decide that all these people need to come together in one place to do that work. So a company, or a charity, or an organization of any kind, unless you're working in Africa, if you're really lucky to do that — most people have to go to an office every day.And so these companies, they build offices. They go out and they buy a building, or they rent a building, or they lease some space, and they fill this space with stuff. They fill it with tables, or desks, chairs, computer equipment, software, Internet access, maybe a fridge, maybe a few other things, and they expect their employees, or their volunteers, to come to that location every day to do great work. It seems like it's perfectly reasonable to ask that.However, if you actually talk to people and even question yourself, and you ask yourself, where do you really want to go when you really need to get something done? You'll find out that people don't say what businesses think they would say. If you ask people the question: Where do you need to go when you need to get something done? Typically, you get three different kinds of answers. One is kind of a place or a location or a room. Another one is a moving object, and a third is a time.So here are some examples. I've been asking people this question for about 10 years: "Where do you go when you really need to get something done?" I'll hear things like, the porch, the deck, the kitchen. I'll hear things like an extra room in the house, the basement, the coffee shop, the library. And then you'll hear things like the train, a plane, a car — so, the commute. And then you'll hear people say, "Well, it doesn't really matter where I am, as long as it's early in the morning or late at night or on the weekends." You almost never hear someone say, "The office." But businesses are spending all this money on this place called the office, and they're making people go to it all the time, yet people don't do work in the office.What is that about?(Laughter)Why is that? Why is that happening? And what you find out is, if you dig a little bit deeper, you find out that people — this is what happens: People go to work, and they're basically trading in their work day for a series of "work moments" — that's what happens at the office. You don't have a work day anymore. You have work moments. It's like the front door of the office is like a Cuisinart, and you walk in and your day is shredded to bits, because you have 15 minutes here, 30 minutes there, and something else happens, you're pulled off your work, then you have 20 minutes, then it's lunch, then you have something else to do ... Then you've got 15 minutes, and someone pulls you aside and asks you a question, and before you know it, it's 5 p.m., and you look back on the day, and you realize that you didn't get anything done. We've all been through this. We probably went through it yesterday or the day before, or the day before that. You look back on your day, and you're like, "I got nothing done today. I was at work. I sat at my desk. I used my expensive computer. I used the software they told me to use. I went to these meetings I was asked to go to. I did these conference calls. I did all this stuff. But I didn't actually do anything. I just did tasks. I didn't actually get meaningful work done."And what you find is that, especially with creative people — designers, programmers, writers, engineers, thinkers — that people really need long stretches of uninterrupted time to get something done. You cannot ask somebody to be creative in 15 minutes and really think about a problem. You might have a quick idea, but to be in deep thought about a problem and really consider a problem carefully, you need long stretches of uninterrupted time. And even though the work day is typically eight hours, how many people here have ever had eight hours to themselves at the office? How about seven hours? Six? Five? Four? When's the last time you had three hours to yourself at the office? Two hours? One, maybe? Very, very few people actually have long stretches of uninterrupted time at an office. And this is why people choose to do work at home, or they might go to the office, but they might go to the office really early in the day, or late at night when no one's around, or they stick around after everyone's left, or go in on the weekends, or they get work done on the plane, in the car or in the train, because there are no distractions.Now there are different kinds of distractions, but not the really bad distractions, which I'll talk about in a minute. And this whole phenomenon of having short bursts of time to get things done reminds me of another thing that doesn't work when you're interrupted, and that is sleep. I think that sleep and work are very closely related — not because you can work while you're sleeping and sleep while you're working. That's not really what I mean. I'm talking specifically about the fact that sleep and work are phase-based, or stage-based, events. Sleep is about sleep phases, or stages — some people call them different things. There are five of them, and in order to get to the really deep ones, the meaningful ones, you have to go through the early ones. If you're interrupted while you're going through the early ones — if someone bumps you in bed, or there's a sound, or whatever happens — you don't just pick up where you left off.If you're interrupted and woken up, you have to start again. So you have to go back a few phases and start again. And what ends up happening — you might have days like this where you wake up at eight or seven in the morning, or whenever you get up, and you're like, "I didn't sleep very well. I did the sleep thing — I went to bed, I laid down, but I didn't really sleep." People say you go "to" sleep, but you don't go to sleep, you go towards sleep; it takes a while. You've got to go through phases and stuff, and if you're interrupted, you don't sleep well. So does anyone here expect someone to sleep well if they're interrupted all night? I don't think anyone would say yes. Why do we expect people to work well if they're being interrupted all day at the office? How can we possibly expect people to do their job if they go to the office and are interrupted? That doesn't really seem like it makes a lot of sense, to me.So what are the interruptions that happen at the office but not at other places? Because in other places, you can have interruptions like the TV, or you could go for a walk, or there's a fridge downstairs, or you've got your own couch, or whatever you want to do. If you talk to certain managers, they'll tell you that they don't want their employees to work at home because of these distractions. They'll sometimes also say, "If I can't see the person, how do I know they're working?" which is ridiculous, but that's one of the excuses that managers give. And I'm one of these managers. I understand. I know how this goes. We all have to improve on this sort of thing. But oftentimes they'll cite distractions: "I can't let someone work at home. They'll watch TV, or do this other thing." It turns out those aren't the things that are distracting, Because those are voluntary distractions. You decide when you want to be distracted by the TV, when you want to turn something on, or when you want to go downstairs or go for a walk. At the office, most of the interruptions and distractions that really cause people not to get work done are involuntary. So let's go through a couple of those.Now, managers and bosses will often have you think that the real distractions at work are things like Facebook and Twitter and YouTube and other websites, and in fact, they'll go so far as to actually ban these sites at work. Some of you may work at places where you can't get to certain sites. I mean, is this China? What the hell is going on here? You can't go to a website at work, and that's the problem? That's why people aren't getting work done, because they're on Facebook and Twitter? That's kind of ridiculous. It's a total decoy. Today's Facebook and Twitter and YouTube, these things are just modern-day smoke breaks. No one cared about letting people take a smoke break for 15 minutes 10 years ago, so why does anyone care if someone goes to Facebook or Twitter or YouTube here and there? Those aren't the real problems in the office.The real problems are what I like to call the M&Ms, the Managers and the Meetings. Those are the real problems in the modern office today. And this is why things don't get done at work, it's because of the M&Ms. Now what's interesting is, if you listen to all the places that people talk about doing work, like at home, in the car, on a plane, late at night, or early in the morning, you don't find managers and meetings. You find a lot of other distractions, but not managers and meetings. So these are the things that you don't find elsewhere, but you do find at the office. And managers are basically people whose job it is to interrupt people. That's pretty much what managers are for. They're for interrupting people. They don't really do the work, so they make sure everyone else is doing work, which is an interruption. We have lots of managers in the world now, and a lot of people in the world, and a lot of interruptions by these managers. They have to check in: "Hey, how's it going? Show me what's up." This sort of thing. They keep interrupting you at the wrong time, while you're actually trying to do something they're paying you to do, they tend to interrupt you. That's kind of bad.But what's even worse is the thing that managers do most of all, which is call meetings. And meetings are just toxic, terrible, poisonous things during the day at work.(Laughter)We all know this to be true, and you would never see a spontaneous meeting called by employees. It doesn't work that way. The manager calls the meeting so the employees can all come together, and it's an incredibly disruptive thing to do to people — to say, "Hey look, we're going to bring 10 people together right now and have a meeting. I don't care what you're doing, you've got to stop doing it, so you can have this meeting." I mean, what are the chances that all 10 people are ready to stop? What if they're thinking about something important, or doing important work? All of a sudden you tell them they have to stop doing that to do something else. So they go into a meeting room, they get together, and they talk about stuff that doesn't really matter, usually. Because meetings aren't work. Meetings are places to go to talk about things you're supposed to be doing later.But meetings also procreate. So one meeting tends to lead to another meeting, which leads to another meeting. There's often too many people in the meetings, and they're very, very expensive to the organization. Companies often think of a one-hour meeting as a one-hour meeting, but that's not true, unless there's only one person. If there are 10 people, it's a 10-hour meeting, not a one-hour meeting. It's 10 hours of productivity taken from the rest of the organization to have this one-hour meeting, which probably should have been handled by two or three people talking for a few minutes. But instead, there's a long scheduled meeting, because meetings are scheduled the way software works, which is in increments of 15 minutes, or 30 minutes, or an hour. You don't schedule an eight-hour meeting with Outlook; you can't. You can go 15 minutes or 30 minutes or 45 minutes or an hour. And so we tend to fill these times up when things should go really quickly.So meetings and managers are two major problems in businesses today, especially at offices. These things don't exist outside of the office. So I have some suggestions to remedy the situation. What can managers do — enlightened managers, hopefully — what can they do to make the office a better place for people to work, so it's not the last resort, but it's the first resort, so that people start to say, "When I really want to get stuff done, I go to the office." Because the offices are well-equipped; everything is there for them to do the work. But they don't want to go there right now, so how do we change that? I have three suggestions to share with you. I have about three minutes, so that'll fit perfectly.We've all heard of the Casual Friday thing. I don't know if people still do that. But how about "No-talk Thursdays?"(Laughter)Pick one Thursday once a month, and cut it in half, just the afternoon — I'll make it easy for you. So just the afternoon, one Thursday. First Thursday of the month, just the afternoon, nobody in the office can talk to each other. Just silence, that's it. And what you'll find is that a tremendous amount of work gets done when no one talks to each other. This is when people actually get stuff done, is when no one's bothering them or interrupting them. Giving someone four hours of uninterrupted time is the best gift you can give anybody at work. It's better than a computer, better than a new monitor, better than new software, or whatever people typically use. Giving them four hours of quiet time at the office is going to be incredibly valuable. If you try that, I think you'll agree, and hopefully you can do it more often. So maybe it's every other week, or every week, once a week, afternoons no one can talk to each other. That's something that you'll find will really, really work.Another thing you can try, is switching from active communication and collaboration, which is like face-to-face stuff — tapping people on the shoulder, saying hi to them, having meetings, and replace that with more passive models of communication, using things like email and instant messaging, or collaboration products, things like that. Now some people might say email is really distracting, I.M. is really distracting, and these other things are really distracting, but they're distracting at a time of your own choice and your own choosing. You can quit the email app; you can't quit your boss. You can quit I.M.; you can't hide your manager. You can put these things away, and then you can be interrupted on your own schedule, at your own time, when you're available, when you're ready to go again. Because work, like sleep, happens in phases. So you'll be going up, doing some work, and then you'll come down from that work, and then maybe it's time to check that email or I.M. There are very, very few things that are that urgent, that need to happen, that need to be answered right this second. So if you're a manager, start encouraging people to use more things like I.M. and email and other things that someone can put away and then get back to you on their own schedule.And the last suggestion I have is that, if you do have a meeting coming up, if you have the power, just cancel it. Just cancel that next meeting.(Laughter)Today's Friday, usually people have meetings on Monday. Just don't have it. I don't mean move it; I mean just erase it from memory, it's gone. And you'll find out that everything will be just fine. All these discussions and decisions you thought you had to make at this one time at 9 a.m. on Monday, just forget about them, and things will be fine. People will have a more open morning, they can actually think. You'll find out all these things you thought you had to do, you don't actually have to do.So those are just three quick suggestions I wanted to give you guys to think about. I hope that some of these ideas were at least provocative enough for managers and bosses and business owners and organizers and people who are in charge of other people, to think about laying off a little bit, and giving people more time to get work done. I think it'll all pay off in the end.So, thanks for listening.(Applause)

to an office every day.

they build offices.

chairs, computer equipment,

software, Internet access,

maybe a fridge, maybe a few other things,

00:01:22.227 --> 00:01:24.808
and they expect their employees,
or their volunteers,

00:01:24.832 --> 00:01:27.481
to come to that location
every day to do great work.

00:01:27.505 --> 00:01:30.426
It seems like it's perfectly
reasonable to ask that.

00:01:30.450 --> 00:01:32.783
However, if you actually talk to people

00:01:32.807 --> 00:01:35.451
and even question yourself,
and you ask yourself,

00:01:35.475 --> 00:01:38.989
where do you really want to go when you
really need to get something done?

00:01:39.013 --> 00:01:42.739
You'll find out that people don't say
what businesses think they would say.

00:01:42.763 --> 00:01:44.260
If you ask people the question:

00:01:44.284 --> 00:01:47.100
Where do you need to go
when you need to get something done?

00:01:47.124 --> 00:01:49.598
Typically, you get three different
kinds of answers.

00:01:49.622 --> 00:01:52.485
One is kind of a place
or a location or a room.

00:01:52.509 --> 00:01:54.453
Another one is a moving object,

00:01:54.477 --> 00:01:56.144
and a third is a time.

00:01:56.168 --> 00:01:58.180
So here are some examples.

00:01:58.204 --> 00:02:01.435
I've been asking people this question
for about 10 years:

00:02:01.459 --> 00:02:04.615
"Where do you go when you
really need to get something done?"

00:02:04.639 --> 00:02:08.187
I'll hear things like, the porch,
the deck, the kitchen.

00:02:08.211 --> 00:02:11.259
I'll hear things like
an extra room in the house,

00:02:11.283 --> 00:02:12.560
the basement,

00:02:12.584 --> 00:02:14.485
the coffee shop, the library.

00:02:15.505 --> 00:02:18.060
And then you'll hear
things like the train,

00:02:18.084 --> 00:02:21.184
a plane, a car -- so, the commute.

00:02:21.624 --> 00:02:23.336
And then you'll hear people say,

00:02:23.360 --> 00:02:25.362
"Well, it doesn't really
matter where I am,

00:02:25.386 --> 00:02:28.898
as long as it's early in the morning
or late at night or on the weekends."

00:02:28.922 --> 00:02:31.747
You almost never hear
someone say, "The office."

00:02:31.771 --> 00:02:35.343
But businesses are spending all this money
on this place called the office,

00:02:35.367 --> 00:02:37.621
and they're making people
go to it all the time,

00:02:37.645 --> 00:02:39.680
yet people don't do work in the office.

00:02:39.704 --> 00:02:40.867
What is that about?

00:02:40.891 --> 00:02:42.351
(Laughter)

00:02:42.375 --> 00:02:45.628
Why is that? Why is that happening?

00:02:46.051 --> 00:02:47.321
And what you find out is,

00:02:47.345 --> 00:02:50.733
if you dig a little bit deeper,
you find out that people --

00:02:50.757 --> 00:02:52.407
this is what happens:

00:02:52.431 --> 00:02:54.160
People go to work,

00:02:54.184 --> 00:02:56.494
and they're basically
trading in their work day

00:02:56.518 --> 00:03:00.010
for a series of "work moments" --
that's what happens at the office.

00:03:00.034 --> 00:03:02.717
You don't have a work day anymore.
You have work moments.

00:03:02.741 --> 00:03:05.519
It's like the front door
of the office is like a Cuisinart,

00:03:05.543 --> 00:03:07.845
and you walk in and your day
is shredded to bits,

00:03:07.869 --> 00:03:10.417
because you have 15 minutes here,
30 minutes there,

00:03:10.441 --> 00:03:13.164
and something else happens,
you're pulled off your work,

00:03:13.188 --> 00:03:17.077
then you have 20 minutes, then it's lunch,
then you have something else to do ...

00:03:17.101 --> 00:03:20.911
Then you've got 15 minutes, and someone
pulls you aside and asks you a question,

00:03:20.935 --> 00:03:23.131
and before you know it, it's 5 p.m.,

00:03:23.155 --> 00:03:24.727
and you look back on the day,

00:03:24.751 --> 00:03:27.782
and you realize that you
didn't get anything done.

00:03:27.806 --> 00:03:29.163
We've all been through this.

00:03:29.187 --> 00:03:32.990
We probably went through it yesterday
or the day before, or the day before that.

00:03:33.014 --> 00:03:34.428
You look back on your day,

00:03:34.452 --> 00:03:36.468
and you're like,
"I got nothing done today.

00:03:36.492 --> 00:03:41.082
I was at work. I sat at my desk.
I used my expensive computer.

00:03:41.106 --> 00:03:43.343
I used the software they told me to use.

00:03:43.367 --> 00:03:45.820
I went to these meetings
I was asked to go to.

00:03:45.844 --> 00:03:48.541
I did these conference calls.
I did all this stuff.

00:03:48.565 --> 00:03:50.934
But I didn't actually do anything.

00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:52.542
I just did tasks.

00:03:52.566 --> 00:03:55.006
I didn't actually get
meaningful work done."

00:03:55.405 --> 00:03:58.341
And what you find is that,
especially with creative people --

00:03:58.365 --> 00:04:03.934
designers, programmers,
writers, engineers, thinkers --

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.846
that people really need long stretches
of uninterrupted time

00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:09.192
to get something done.

00:04:09.216 --> 00:04:12.644
You cannot ask somebody
to be creative in 15 minutes

00:04:12.668 --> 00:04:14.287
and really think about a problem.

00:04:14.311 --> 00:04:15.677
You might have a quick idea,

00:04:15.701 --> 00:04:19.660
but to be in deep thought about a problem
and really consider a problem carefully,

00:04:19.684 --> 00:04:22.072
you need long stretches
of uninterrupted time.

00:04:22.569 --> 00:04:25.271
And even though the work day
is typically eight hours,

00:04:25.295 --> 00:04:28.850
how many people here have ever had
eight hours to themselves at the office?

00:04:28.874 --> 00:04:30.041
How about seven hours?

00:04:30.065 --> 00:04:33.273
Six? Five? Four?

00:04:33.297 --> 00:04:36.449
When's the last time you had
three hours to yourself at the office?

00:04:36.473 --> 00:04:38.495
Two hours? One, maybe?

00:04:38.519 --> 00:04:40.234
Very, very few people actually have

00:04:40.258 --> 00:04:42.932
long stretches of uninterrupted
time at an office.

00:04:42.956 --> 00:04:46.486
And this is why people
choose to do work at home,

00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:48.089
or they might go to the office,

00:04:48.113 --> 00:04:50.748
but they might go to the office
really early in the day,

00:04:50.772 --> 00:04:52.598
or late at night when no one's around,

00:04:52.622 --> 00:04:54.690
or they stick around
after everyone's left,

00:04:54.714 --> 00:04:56.128
or go in on the weekends,

00:04:56.152 --> 00:04:59.243
or they get work done on the plane,
in the car or in the train,

00:04:59.267 --> 00:05:01.172
because there are no distractions.

00:05:01.196 --> 00:05:03.391
Now there are different
kinds of distractions,

00:05:03.415 --> 00:05:06.804
but not the really bad distractions,
which I'll talk about in a minute.

00:05:06.828 --> 00:05:11.292
And this whole phenomenon of having
short bursts of time to get things done

00:05:11.316 --> 00:05:14.958
reminds me of another thing
that doesn't work when you're interrupted,

00:05:14.982 --> 00:05:16.167
and that is sleep.

00:05:16.729 --> 00:05:19.918
I think that sleep and work
are very closely related --

00:05:19.942 --> 00:05:23.640
not because you can work while you're
sleeping and sleep while you're working.

00:05:23.664 --> 00:05:25.108
That's not really what I mean.

00:05:25.132 --> 00:05:31.203
I'm talking specifically about the fact
that sleep and work are phase-based,

00:05:31.227 --> 00:05:32.958
or stage-based, events.

00:05:33.282 --> 00:05:39.337
Sleep is about sleep phases, or stages --
some people call them different things.

00:05:39.361 --> 00:05:43.195
There are five of them, and in order
to get to the really deep ones,

00:05:43.219 --> 00:05:45.988
the meaningful ones,
you have to go through the early ones.

00:05:46.012 --> 00:05:49.203
If you're interrupted while you're
going through the early ones --

00:05:49.227 --> 00:05:52.934
if someone bumps you in bed,
or there's a sound, or whatever happens --

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
you don't just pick up where you left off.

00:05:54.982 --> 00:05:56.934
If you're interrupted and woken up,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.696
you have to start again.

00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:01.934
So you have to go back
a few phases and start again.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.725
And what ends up happening --
you might have days like this

00:06:04.749 --> 00:06:08.297
where you wake up at eight or seven
in the morning, or whenever you get up,

00:06:08.321 --> 00:06:10.437
and you're like,
"I didn't sleep very well.

00:06:10.461 --> 00:06:13.029
I did the sleep thing --
I went to bed, I laid down,

00:06:13.053 --> 00:06:15.431
but I didn't really sleep."

00:06:15.455 --> 00:06:17.821
People say you go "to" sleep,

00:06:17.845 --> 00:06:20.963
but you don't go to sleep,
you go towards sleep; it takes a while.

00:06:20.987 --> 00:06:23.042
You've got to go through phases and stuff,

00:06:23.066 --> 00:06:25.375
and if you're interrupted,
you don't sleep well.

00:06:25.399 --> 00:06:27.755
So does anyone here
expect someone to sleep well

00:06:27.779 --> 00:06:29.361
if they're interrupted all night?

00:06:29.385 --> 00:06:31.099
I don't think anyone would say yes.

00:06:31.123 --> 00:06:33.448
Why do we expect people to work well

00:06:33.472 --> 00:06:35.944
if they're being interrupted
all day at the office?

00:06:35.968 --> 00:06:38.402
How can we possibly expect
people to do their job

00:06:38.426 --> 00:06:40.531
if they go to the office
and are interrupted?

00:06:40.555 --> 00:06:43.462
That doesn't really seem
like it makes a lot of sense, to me.

00:06:43.486 --> 00:06:47.354
So what are the interruptions that happen
at the office but not at other places?

00:06:47.378 --> 00:06:51.639
Because in other places, you can have
interruptions like the TV,

00:06:51.663 --> 00:06:54.934
or you could go for a walk,
or there's a fridge downstairs,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.063
or you've got your own couch,
or whatever you want to do.

00:06:58.087 --> 00:07:00.896
If you talk to certain managers,
they'll tell you

00:07:00.920 --> 00:07:03.491
that they don't want
their employees to work at home

00:07:03.515 --> 00:07:05.412
because of these distractions.

00:07:05.436 --> 00:07:08.467
They'll sometimes also say,

00:07:08.491 --> 00:07:11.334
"If I can't see the person,
how do I know they're working?"

00:07:11.358 --> 00:07:14.659
which is ridiculous, but that's one
of the excuses that managers give.

00:07:14.683 --> 00:07:17.940
And I'm one of these managers.
I understand. I know how this goes.

00:07:17.964 --> 00:07:20.687
We all have to improve
on this sort of thing.

00:07:20.711 --> 00:07:22.681
But oftentimes they'll cite distractions:

00:07:22.705 --> 00:07:24.339
"I can't let someone work at home.

00:07:24.363 --> 00:07:26.379
They'll watch TV, or do this other thing."

00:07:26.403 --> 00:07:29.138
It turns out those aren't
the things that are distracting,

00:07:29.162 --> 00:07:31.118
Because those are voluntary distractions.

00:07:31.142 --> 00:07:33.594
You decide when you want
to be distracted by the TV,

00:07:33.618 --> 00:07:35.309
when you want to turn something on,

00:07:35.333 --> 00:07:37.727
or when you want to go
downstairs or go for a walk.

00:07:37.751 --> 00:07:38.902
At the office,

00:07:38.926 --> 00:07:40.949
most of the interruptions and distractions

00:07:40.973 --> 00:07:44.090
that really cause people not
to get work done are involuntary.

00:07:44.114 --> 00:07:47.225
So let's go through a couple of those.

00:07:47.249 --> 00:07:50.566
Now, managers and bosses
will often have you think

00:07:50.590 --> 00:07:52.594
that the real distractions at work

00:07:52.618 --> 00:07:55.428
are things like Facebook and Twitter

00:07:55.452 --> 00:07:58.622
and YouTube and other websites,

00:07:58.646 --> 00:08:02.488
and in fact, they'll go so far
as to actually ban these sites at work.

00:08:02.512 --> 00:08:05.853
Some of you may work at places
where you can't get to certain sites.

00:08:05.877 --> 00:08:08.496
I mean, is this China?
What the hell is going on here?

00:08:08.520 --> 00:08:11.263
You can't go to a website at work,
and that's the problem?

00:08:11.287 --> 00:08:13.295
That's why people aren't
getting work done,

00:08:13.319 --> 00:08:15.247
because they're on Facebook and Twitter?

00:08:15.271 --> 00:08:17.524
That's kind of ridiculous.
It's a total decoy.

00:08:18.255 --> 00:08:21.672
Today's Facebook and Twitter and YouTube,

00:08:21.696 --> 00:08:23.934
these things are just
modern-day smoke breaks.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.973
No one cared about letting people take
a smoke break for 15 minutes 10 years ago,

00:08:27.997 --> 00:08:30.615
so why does anyone care
if someone goes to Facebook

00:08:30.639 --> 00:08:32.750
or Twitter or YouTube here and there?

00:08:32.774 --> 00:08:35.351
Those aren't the real
problems in the office.

00:08:35.375 --> 00:08:38.986
The real problems are
what I like to call the M&Ms,

00:08:39.010 --> 00:08:41.263
the Managers and the Meetings.

00:08:41.287 --> 00:08:44.676
Those are the real problems
in the modern office today.

00:08:44.700 --> 00:08:47.180
And this is why
things don't get done at work,

00:08:47.204 --> 00:08:49.004
it's because of the M&Ms.

00:08:49.028 --> 00:08:51.330
Now what's interesting is,

00:08:51.354 --> 00:08:54.495
if you listen to all the places
that people talk about doing work,

00:08:54.519 --> 00:08:58.483
like at home, in the car, on a plane,
late at night, or early in the morning,

00:08:58.507 --> 00:09:00.638
you don't find managers and meetings.

00:09:00.662 --> 00:09:03.899
You find a lot of other distractions,
but not managers and meetings.

00:09:03.923 --> 00:09:06.900
So these are the things
that you don't find elsewhere,

00:09:06.924 --> 00:09:08.519
but you do find at the office.

00:09:09.329 --> 00:09:12.680
And managers are basically people
whose job it is to interrupt people.

00:09:12.704 --> 00:09:16.196
That's pretty much what managers are for.
They're for interrupting people.

00:09:16.220 --> 00:09:20.059
They don't really do the work, so they
make sure everyone else is doing work,

00:09:20.083 --> 00:09:21.807
which is an interruption.

00:09:21.831 --> 00:09:25.425
We have lots of managers in the world now,
and a lot of people in the world,

00:09:25.449 --> 00:09:27.550
and a lot of interruptions
by these managers.

00:09:27.574 --> 00:09:29.627
They have to check in:
"Hey, how's it going?

00:09:29.651 --> 00:09:31.535
Show me what's up." This sort of thing.

00:09:31.559 --> 00:09:33.717
They keep interrupting you
at the wrong time,

00:09:33.741 --> 00:09:37.042
while you're actually trying to do
something they're paying you to do,

00:09:37.066 --> 00:09:38.469
they tend to interrupt you.

00:09:38.493 --> 00:09:40.056
That's kind of bad.

00:09:40.080 --> 00:09:43.191
But what's even worse is the thing
that managers do most of all,

00:09:43.215 --> 00:09:44.662
which is call meetings.

00:09:44.686 --> 00:09:47.232
And meetings are just toxic,

00:09:47.256 --> 00:09:50.258
terrible, poisonous things

00:09:50.282 --> 00:09:51.701
during the day at work.

00:09:51.725 --> 00:09:52.941
(Laughter)

00:09:52.965 --> 00:09:54.752
We all know this to be true,

00:09:54.776 --> 00:09:57.997
and you would never see a spontaneous
meeting called by employees.

00:09:58.021 --> 00:09:59.282
It doesn't work that way.

00:09:59.306 --> 00:10:01.034
The manager calls the meeting

00:10:01.058 --> 00:10:02.973
so the employees can all come together,

00:10:02.997 --> 00:10:05.720
and it's an incredibly disruptive
thing to do to people --

00:10:05.744 --> 00:10:06.934
to say, "Hey look,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.656
we're going to bring 10 people
together right now and have a meeting.

00:10:10.680 --> 00:10:12.172
I don't care what you're doing,

00:10:12.196 --> 00:10:15.203
you've got to stop doing it,
so you can have this meeting."

00:10:15.227 --> 00:10:18.601
I mean, what are the chances
that all 10 people are ready to stop?

00:10:18.625 --> 00:10:22.378
What if they're thinking about something
important, or doing important work?

00:10:22.402 --> 00:10:26.191
All of a sudden you tell them they have
to stop doing that to do something else.

00:10:26.215 --> 00:10:28.934
So they go into a meeting room,
they get together,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.230
and they talk about stuff
that doesn't really matter, usually.

00:10:32.254 --> 00:10:33.898
Because meetings aren't work.

00:10:33.922 --> 00:10:36.088
Meetings are places to go
to talk about things

00:10:36.112 --> 00:10:37.809
you're supposed to be doing later.

00:10:37.833 --> 00:10:39.804
But meetings also procreate.

00:10:39.828 --> 00:10:42.093
So one meeting tends
to lead to another meeting,

00:10:42.117 --> 00:10:43.602
which leads to another meeting.

00:10:43.626 --> 00:10:45.832
There's often too many people
in the meetings,

00:10:45.856 --> 00:10:48.581
and they're very, very expensive
to the organization.

00:10:48.605 --> 00:10:51.730
Companies often think of a one-hour
meeting as a one-hour meeting,

00:10:51.754 --> 00:10:54.215
but that's not true,
unless there's only one person.

00:10:54.239 --> 00:10:57.763
If there are 10 people, it's a 10-hour
meeting, not a one-hour meeting.

00:10:57.787 --> 00:11:01.064
It's 10 hours of productivity taken
from the rest of the organization

00:11:01.088 --> 00:11:04.427
to have this one-hour meeting,
which probably should have been handled

00:11:04.451 --> 00:11:06.934
by two or three people
talking for a few minutes.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.497
But instead, there's a long
scheduled meeting,

00:11:09.521 --> 00:11:12.092
because meetings are scheduled
the way software works,

00:11:12.116 --> 00:11:15.517
which is in increments of 15 minutes,
or 30 minutes, or an hour.

00:11:15.541 --> 00:11:19.184
You don't schedule an eight-hour meeting
with Outlook; you can't.

00:11:19.208 --> 00:11:22.182
You can go 15 minutes or 30 minutes
or 45 minutes or an hour.

00:11:22.206 --> 00:11:24.180
And so we tend to fill these times up

00:11:24.204 --> 00:11:26.363
when things should go really quickly.

00:11:26.387 --> 00:11:30.037
So meetings and managers are
two major problems in businesses today,

00:11:30.061 --> 00:11:31.220
especially at offices.

00:11:31.244 --> 00:11:33.890
These things don't exist
outside of the office.

00:11:34.386 --> 00:11:39.187
So I have some suggestions
to remedy the situation.

00:11:39.211 --> 00:11:40.934
What can managers do --

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.934
enlightened managers, hopefully --

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.430
what can they do to make the office
a better place for people to work,

00:11:46.454 --> 00:11:49.299
so it's not the last resort,
but it's the first resort,

00:11:49.323 --> 00:11:50.665
so that people start to say,

00:11:50.689 --> 00:11:53.466
"When I really want to get stuff done,
I go to the office."

00:11:53.490 --> 00:11:55.404
Because the offices are well-equipped;

00:11:55.428 --> 00:11:57.562
everything is there
for them to do the work.

00:11:57.586 --> 00:12:00.847
But they don't want to go there right
now, so how do we change that?

00:12:00.871 --> 00:12:02.905
I have three suggestions
to share with you.

00:12:02.929 --> 00:12:05.800
I have about three minutes,
so that'll fit perfectly.

00:12:05.824 --> 00:12:08.661
We've all heard
of the Casual Friday thing.

00:12:08.685 --> 00:12:10.534
I don't know if people still do that.

00:12:10.558 --> 00:12:12.234
But how about "No-talk Thursdays?"

00:12:12.258 --> 00:12:14.290
(Laughter)

00:12:14.314 --> 00:12:17.260
Pick one Thursday once a month,

00:12:17.284 --> 00:12:20.595
and cut it in half, just the afternoon --
I'll make it easy for you.

00:12:20.619 --> 00:12:22.349
So just the afternoon, one Thursday.

00:12:22.373 --> 00:12:24.627
First Thursday of the month,
just the afternoon,

00:12:24.651 --> 00:12:26.715
nobody in the office
can talk to each other.

00:12:26.739 --> 00:12:28.277
Just silence, that's it.

00:12:28.301 --> 00:12:29.934
And what you'll find

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.366
is that a tremendous amount
of work gets done

00:12:32.390 --> 00:12:33.994
when no one talks to each other.

00:12:34.018 --> 00:12:36.082
This is when people
actually get stuff done,

00:12:36.106 --> 00:12:38.622
is when no one's bothering them
or interrupting them.

00:12:38.646 --> 00:12:41.607
Giving someone four hours
of uninterrupted time

00:12:41.631 --> 00:12:43.805
is the best gift you can
give anybody at work.

00:12:43.829 --> 00:12:45.242
It's better than a computer,

00:12:45.266 --> 00:12:48.020
better than a new monitor,
better than new software,

00:12:48.044 --> 00:12:50.019
or whatever people typically use.

00:12:50.043 --> 00:12:52.447
Giving them four hours
of quiet time at the office

00:12:52.471 --> 00:12:54.392
is going to be incredibly valuable.

00:12:54.416 --> 00:12:58.384
If you try that, I think you'll agree,
and hopefully you can do it more often.

00:12:58.408 --> 00:13:00.130
So maybe it's every other week,

00:13:00.154 --> 00:13:01.934
or every week, once a week,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.011
afternoons no one can talk to each other.

00:13:04.035 --> 00:13:07.122
That's something that you'll find
will really, really work.

00:13:07.146 --> 00:13:09.448
Another thing you can try,

00:13:09.472 --> 00:13:12.934
is switching from active
communication and collaboration,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.149
which is like face-to-face stuff --
tapping people on the shoulder,

00:13:16.173 --> 00:13:18.149
saying hi to them, having meetings,

00:13:18.173 --> 00:13:20.959
and replace that with more
passive models of communication,

00:13:20.983 --> 00:13:23.284
using things like email
and instant messaging,

00:13:23.308 --> 00:13:26.260
or collaboration products,
things like that.

00:13:26.586 --> 00:13:29.507
Now some people might say
email is really distracting,

00:13:29.531 --> 00:13:33.101
I.M. is really distracting, and these
other things are really distracting,

00:13:33.125 --> 00:13:36.697
but they're distracting at a time
of your own choice and your own choosing.

00:13:36.721 --> 00:13:39.529
You can quit the email app;
you can't quit your boss.

00:13:39.553 --> 00:13:41.331
You can quit I.M.;

00:13:41.355 --> 00:13:43.172
you can't hide your manager.

00:13:43.196 --> 00:13:44.934
You can put these things away,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.339
and then you can be interrupted
on your own schedule, at your own time,

00:13:48.363 --> 00:13:50.840
when you're available,
when you're ready to go again.

00:13:50.864 --> 00:13:52.934
Because work, like sleep,
happens in phases.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.051
So you'll be going up, doing some work,

00:13:55.075 --> 00:13:57.034
and then you'll come down from that work,

00:13:57.058 --> 00:13:59.510
and then maybe it's time
to check that email or I.M.

00:13:59.534 --> 00:14:02.035
There are very, very few things
that are that urgent,

00:14:02.059 --> 00:14:05.106
that need to happen, that need
to be answered right this second.

00:14:05.130 --> 00:14:06.305
So if you're a manager,

00:14:06.329 --> 00:14:09.313
start encouraging people to use
more things like I.M. and email

00:14:09.337 --> 00:14:11.353
and other things that someone can put away

00:14:11.377 --> 00:14:13.578
and then get back to you
on their own schedule.

00:14:13.602 --> 00:14:17.181
And the last suggestion I have is that,

00:14:17.205 --> 00:14:18.934
if you do have a meeting coming up,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.584
if you have the power, just cancel it.

00:14:22.608 --> 00:14:24.068
Just cancel that next meeting.

00:14:24.092 --> 00:14:25.258
(Laughter)

00:14:25.282 --> 00:14:27.927
Today's Friday, usually people
have meetings on Monday.

00:14:27.951 --> 00:14:29.113
Just don't have it.

00:14:29.137 --> 00:14:30.542
I don't mean move it;

00:14:30.566 --> 00:14:33.208
I mean just erase it
from memory, it's gone.

00:14:33.232 --> 00:14:35.820
And you'll find out that everything
will be just fine.

00:14:35.844 --> 00:14:38.860
All these discussions and decisions
you thought you had to make

00:14:38.884 --> 00:14:40.668
at this one time at 9 a.m. on Monday,

00:14:40.692 --> 00:14:42.989
just forget about them,
and things will be fine.

00:14:43.013 --> 00:14:45.994
People will have a more open morning,
they can actually think.

00:14:46.018 --> 00:14:48.793
You'll find out all these things
you thought you had to do,

00:14:48.817 --> 00:14:50.270
you don't actually have to do.

00:14:50.294 --> 00:14:54.286
So those are just three quick suggestions
I wanted to give you guys to think about.

00:14:54.310 --> 00:14:57.335
I hope that some of these ideas
were at least provocative enough

00:14:57.359 --> 00:14:59.465
for managers and bosses
and business owners

00:14:59.489 --> 00:15:02.305
and organizers and people
who are in charge of other people,

00:15:02.329 --> 00:15:04.200
to think about laying off a little bit,

00:15:04.224 --> 00:15:06.359
and giving people more time
to get work done.

00:15:06.383 --> 00:15:08.193
I think it'll all pay off in the end.

00:15:08.217 --> 00:15:10.219
So, thanks for listening.

00:15:10.243 --> 00:15:11.902
(Applause)
